For example, if an Insider has Inside Information relating to an Issuer, A, of Financial Instruments, then a "Related Instrument" could include a Derivative relating to the Financial Instruments of A or another Financial Instrument in a member of A's Group, if the price or value of that other Financial Instrument depends, in whole or in part, on the price or value of Financial Instruments of A.

question: In a Takeover or Merger, when may the Regulator consent to the release of a holding lock so that holders of Restricted Securities can accept an offer or otherwise transfer or cancel Securities, and what preconditions must be satisfied before the Regulator will provide that consent (including any requirements about offer scope, acceptance levels by non-restricted holders, and written re-imposition arrangements if the transaction does not proceed or securities are not acquired)?
gold_answer: The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or to transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover [#TGT:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67]. However, the Regulator will not provide its consent unless, to the extent applicable, specified conditions are met [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]. Where there is an offer for Securities, the offer must cover all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities; holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities to which the offer relates must have accepted; and if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock be immediately re-imposed for each Security not bought by the offeror. Where the offer is conducted by way of a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held must agree in writing that the holding lock be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
source_text:
Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator will not provide its consent under Rule 9.6.11 unless, to the extent to which they are applicable, all the following requirements are met:
(1)	where there is an offer for Securities:
(a)	the offer is for all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all the Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities;
(b)	holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities, to which the offer relates, have accepted; and
(c)	if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder agree in writing that the holding lock (imposed under Rule 9.6.9) be immediately re-imposed for each Security that is not bought by the offeror under the offer; and
(2)	where the offer is to be conducted by way of a ‘scheme’, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
target_text: Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.

question: Where an Applicant has less than three years of audited financial statements and the Regulator generally expects quarterly cash reporting in that circumstance, what audited accounts must the Applicant have published or filed, and what minimum content and assurance characteristics must those accounts meet, including any Regulator discretion to accept a shorter period?
gold_answer: When an Applicant has less than three years of audited financial statements, the Regulator may generally require quarterly cash reporting from the relevant Reporting Entity in that circumstance, including where the Listed Entity is admitted under the assets eligibility test or where the Regulator considers quarterly cash reports necessary for other reasons such as a cash-box admission [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8]. In parallel, the Applicant must still have published or filed audited accounts that cover a prior period of three years, unless the Regulator accepts a shorter period, which provides a mechanism to address situations where a full three-year history is not available [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. Those audited accounts must be consolidated for the Applicant and any of its subsidiary undertakings, prepared in accordance with IFRS or other standards acceptable to the Regulator, and audited and reported on by auditors using IAASB auditing standards or other standards acceptable to the Regulator [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. Accordingly, even if the Regulator accepts a shorter audited period, the Applicant must ensure the accounts meet the specified consolidation, accounting framework, and audit-standard requirements while also anticipating the Regulator’s expectation of quarterly cash reporting in the identified circumstances [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8].
source_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.

question: If a Relevant Person wants to use another firm to do parts of CDD, when can it do that, and what must it consider to decide whether the other country’s AML/TFS rules are equivalent to FATF standards?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person can rely on another firm for parts of CDD only if several conditions are met and it has made an equivalence judgement about the other country’s AML/TFS regime. The permission to rely applies only where the Relevant Person immediately gets the necessary CDD information from the third party, takes adequate steps to be satisfied that certified copies of the documents used for the CDD work will be available on request without delay, confirms the third party has not used an exception from doing the CDD elements the Relevant Person wants to rely on, and ensures the information is up to date where applicable [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275]. A key condition is that the third party is regulated (including AML/TFS compliance requirements) by a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator or other competent authority in a country with AML/TFS regulations equivalent to FATF standards and is supervised for compliance. In making that equivalence assessment, the Relevant Person must take into account factors such as FATF/IMF/World Bank/OECD or other international reports, relevant memberships, contextual factors like political stability and corruption, recent criticism (including advisory notices and public assessments), and whether there are adequate co-operation arrangements between the foreign AML/TFS regulator and the Regulator [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4].

question: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree in writing that the withdrawal-of-consent rules do not apply, and what does that mean for whether the Customer can withdraw consent to a Third Party Transaction before it can no longer be revoked?
gold_answer: Yes. When the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that certain rules do not apply, including Rule 20.7.3 and 20.7.4 (withdrawal of consent) and Rule 20.8.2 (revocation of a Payment Order) [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. Separately, the Customer is permitted to withdraw its consent to an individual Third Party Transaction at any time before the point when that Third Party Transaction can no longer be revoked, with that point defined by Rule 20.8.2; in other words, the Customer “may withdraw its consent” up to that revocation cut-off [#TGT:84c622c5-b22e-4360-9f94-1bd99e99f12c]. Putting the two together, the target permission operates as the default position, but the source allows the parties (only in the non-Natural Person scenario) to contract out of the withdrawal-of-consent framework by written agreement. If they do so, the Customer’s ability to withdraw consent on the timing described in the target may be changed or removed to the extent the agreed disapplication covers the relevant rules, so the written agreement should clearly state what is being disapplied and what, if anything, replaces it.
target_text: The Customer may withdraw its consent to an individual Third Party Transaction at any time before the point at which the Third Party Transaction can no longer be revoked as set out in Rule 20.8.2.

question: If the Regulator shares Confidential Information, can it put conditions on that permission—like requiring consents or requiring the receiver to follow confidentiality limits that are at least equivalent to the usual restrictions?
gold_answer: Yes. When the Regulator discloses Confidential Information, it is permitted to include conditions as part of the permission to disclose, to the extent the Regulator considers appropriate. Those conditions can cover practical safeguards around the disclosure, including requiring that consents are obtained and, where appropriate, requiring that the recipient treats the information under restrictions on further disclosure that are at least equivalent to the relevant confidentiality restrictions. In other words, the Regulator can allow disclosure but only on terms that control how the information is handled after it is shared, rather than granting an unrestricted permission. In addition, the same permission allows the Regulator to restrict the uses to which the disclosed Confidential Information may be put, so the recipient may be limited not only in whether it can re-disclose the information but also in what it can do with it. This aligns with the statement that the Regulator may impose conditions on the information disclosed (including consents and equivalent restrictions) and may restrict uses [#SRC:5b971fba-9c2c-40a0-9b54-e38c1d4d3350], and with the permission being expressly subject to such conditions insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate [#TGT:98d99b60-b14d-4468-becd-e2c79c8f8b4a].
source_text:
Section 199(3) of the FSMR enables the Regulator to, among other things:
(a)	impose conditions on the information disclosed, which may relate to, among other things, the obtaining of consents or, where appropriate, subjecting information received to restrictions on disclosure that are at least equivalent to those set out in section 198, per paragraph 199(3)(a); and
(b)	restrict the uses to which the Confidential Information disclosed may be put.
target_text:
Any disclosure by the Regulator pursuant to subsection  ‎(1) may include, insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate, provisions—
(a)	making any permission to disclose Confidential Information subject to conditions (which may relate to the obtaining of consents, subjecting information received to restrictions on disclosure of Confidential Information at least equivalent to those set out in section 198 or any other matter); and
(b)	restricting the uses to which Confidential Information disclosed may be put.

question: Where Eligible Green Portfolio Assets in an ADGM Green Portfolio are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, must the Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager still appoint a third party to provide ongoing and at least annual attestation of compliance, and how does this interact with the limitation that the attestation obligation applies only to the portion invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio is generally required to appoint a third party to attest, on an ongoing basis and at least annually, to the Investment Manager’s compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement, but that obligation is scoped to apply only to the portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. Separately, the scope provision states that the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]. Read together, the Investment Manager must apply the attestation obligation only to the relevant portion of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that falls within the stated applicability, and must exclude from that attestation any Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that meet the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark condition. In practice, this means the third-party appointment and attestation coverage should be calibrated to the portfolio’s composition so that only in-scope assets are attested and the benchmark-tracking assets are carved out.
source_text: Under Rule 3.8.6, the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets which are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(b).
target_text: The Green Porftolio Attestation Requirement. The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually. This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(a). This requirement is referred to as the “Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement”.

question: In defining when a filed Prospectus becomes an Approved Prospectus, how do the Regulations’ general test for approval under the Rules interact with the requirement that the Regulator issue an approval notice to the Applicant, including where the Prospectus consists of multiple documents?
gold_answer: Read together, the two definitions establish both a general criterion and a specific procedural condition for when a Prospectus attains “Approved Prospectus” status. Under the Regulations, a Prospectus qualifies as an Approved Prospectus when it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and references to a Prospectus in the Regulations are generally to an Approved Prospectus unless context indicates otherwise [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1]. The Source clarifies that merely filing a Prospectus with the Regulator does not meet that status unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. That notice must cover the Prospectus (or, where applicable, the Supplementary Prospectus), and if the Prospectus comprises multiple documents, the notice must state approval of all of those documents [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. Accordingly, the general “approved in accordance with the Rules” standard is operationalized by requiring an explicit approval notice to the Applicant, and the multi-document structure does not dilute the approval requirement; it expands the scope of what must be expressly approved.
source_text:
A Prospectus filed with the Regulator is not an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2)(a) of the FSMR unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval:
(a)	of the Prospectus or the Supplementary Prospectus as the case may be; and
(b)	in the case of a Prospectus in (a) comprising multiple documents, of all the multiple documents.
target_text:
For the purposes of subsection ‎(1)—
(a)	a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules; and
(b)	a reference to a Prospectus made by or under these Regulations is a reference to an Approved Prospectus, unless the context requires otherwise.

question: If the Third Party Provider confirms a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, when must it refund, and does that timing still apply if it reasonably suspects the Customer is acting fraudulently?
gold_answer: Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide a refund as soon as practicable and no later than the end of the day after the day it made that confirmation [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. But that refund-timing requirement is not universal. The requirement to provide a refund within the prescribed timeframe does not apply where the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]. Putting both points together: the default expectation is a prompt refund after confirmation, with a clear latest deadline, but the Third Party Provider is not required to meet the prescribed refund timeframe if it has reasonable grounds for suspecting Customer fraud. The key practical distinction is that the trigger for the refund deadline is the Third Party Provider’s confirmation about the transaction’s status, while the exception depends on the Third Party Provider having reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer.
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The requirement to provide a refund within the timeframe prescribed in Rule 20.12.2 does not apply where the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer.
target_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, how must it reflect the collateral’s credit risk mitigation effects in its RWA calculation process, including how it determines the Exposure value (E) and the applicable risk weight for the collateralised and uncollateralised portions?
gold_answer: In calculating RWA for CR Exposures, an Authorised Person must determine an Exposure value (E) for each on- and off-balance sheet asset using the applicable exposure measurement methodology and must recognise the effects of any applicable CRM as part of that process [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]. Where the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, it is permitted to recognise the CRM effects by splitting the CR Exposure into two components: a collateralised portion and an uncollateralised portion [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb]. For the collateralised portion, E is set to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the applicable risk weight is the CRW that applies to that collateral as if the Authorised Person had a direct exposure to it. For the uncollateralised portion, E is the original E of the CR Exposure reduced by the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the applicable risk weight is the CRW that applies to the obligor. The resulting RWA amounts are then calculated using the E × CRW approach and aggregated across exposures as required [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368].
source_text:
Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows:
(a) 	break down the Exposure into -
(i) 	a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and
(ii) 	an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral;
and
(b) 	for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use:
(i) 	for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and
(ii) 	for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

question: When an Authorised Person must determine its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital based on its Total Risk Exposure Amount and the jurisdictions of its private sector credit exposures, what calculation steps must it follow to derive the weighted average Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate that is then applied in the buffer amount?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. To obtain that weighted average rate, it must follow a jurisdiction-by-jurisdiction procedure: first, identify each jurisdiction in which it has private sector credit exposures and determine the portion of Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to those private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction. Next, divide that jurisdiction-specific amount by the Total Risk Exposure Amount relating to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions, and multiply the resulting fraction by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate for that jurisdiction. Finally, sum the resulting contributions across all jurisdictions to produce the single weighted average rate that is used as the multiplier in the CET1 buffer calculation [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124].
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text:
Weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. The weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates shall be calculated by:
(a)	for each jurisdiction in which the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, dividing the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions and multiplying it by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and
(b)	summing those contributions across all jurisdictions.

question: If the Investigator wants to get relevant information or documents during an investigation and chooses the compulsory route instead of asking voluntarily, what can the Investigator require by written notice from the Person Under Investigation or from someone else?
gold_answer: The Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents during an investigation either on a compulsory basis or on a voluntary basis, meaning the Investigator can choose between requiring material and requesting it cooperatively depending on the circumstances [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4]. If the Investigator uses the compulsory approach, the TARGET explains that the Investigator may issue a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that other person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. The notice can require the person to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions, to produce specified documents (or a specified type of documents) at a specified time and place, and to provide information or assistance that the Investigator requires. It can also require the person to allow the Investigator to enter the person’s business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy documents kept there. Together, the SOURCE sets out the overall ability to obtain material compulsorily or voluntarily, and the TARGET lists what the compulsory written notice can demand.
source_text: Power to require documents or information . During an investigation, the Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents either on a compulsory basis, principally through the exercise of its powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR, or on a voluntary basis.

question: If an Authorised Person has a rated short term corporate CR Exposure that gets a 50% or 100% risk weight, what is the lowest risk weight they can use for an unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate, and does that match the table’s unrated corporate risk weight?
gold_answer: When the Authorised Person has a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue-specific external credit assessment that results in a 50% or 100% risk weight, they must apply a risk weight of not lower than 100% to any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad]. The corporate asset class table also sets the risk weight for “Unrated” corporate exposures at 100% (subject to the stated rule cross-references) [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4]. So, in this situation, the minimum required by the rule for the unrated short term exposure and the table’s unrated corporate risk weight point to the same outcome: 100%. Practically, the Authorised Person should treat the unrated short term exposure to that corporate as 100% and ensure it is not assigned anything lower, even though the related rated short term issue may have received a lower risk weight (50%) or the same risk weight (100%). This approach satisfies both the specific minimum floor tied to the rated short term exposure and the general unrated corporate treatment in the table.
source_text:
Corporate asset class. The risk weight for any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class that does not have an external credit assessment by a recognised external credit rating agency must be the risk weight determined in accordance with the table under Rule 4.12.13 or the risk weight that is applicable to an CR Exposure to the central government of the jurisdiction in which the corporate is incorporated or established, whichever is higher. If a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue specific external credit assessment:
(a)	attracts a risk weight of 50% or 100%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of not lower than 100% to any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate; or
(b)	attracts a risk weight of 150%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of 150% to any unrated CR Exposure (whether long term or short term) to the same corporate.
target_text:
Corporate asset class. Subject to Rules 4.12.14 and 4.12.15, an Authorised Person must risk weight any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class in accordance with the following table:
Risk Weights for the corporate asset class
/Table Start

Credit Quality Grade	1	2	3	4	5	6	Unrated
Risk Weight	20%	50%	100%	100%	150%	150%	100%

/Table End

question: If a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company has Long-Term Insurance Business that must sit in a Long-Term Insurance Fund, what does it have to do, and can the Regulator still require it to set up one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds?
gold_answer: If a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must take one of two required steps: either (a) establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds, or (b) notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469]. In addition to that required choice, the Regulator has a separate discretionary power: it may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of that business [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7]. This means the Captive Insurer cannot treat the written notification option as guaranteed in all cases. Even where the Captive Insurer would otherwise comply by notifying the Regulator that it is deemed a single Long-Term Insurance Fund, the Regulator can still direct the establishment of one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for the relevant business (or part of it), and the Captive Insurer must then align its actions with that direction.
source_text:
Residual discretion of the Regulator
Notwithstanding Rule 8.1.1 and 8.1.2, the Regulator may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds in respect of its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of such business.
target_text:
Captive Insurer not a Cell Company
Where a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that, under the provisions of Rule ‎8.2, must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must either:
(a)	establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds; or
(b)	notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund.

question: If an Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission lets it do Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal, but it is also authorised for things like Managing Assets or Providing Custody (other than for a Fund), how do you decide whether it is Category 2 or Category 3C? What role do the “not limited in scope” dealing condition and the “must not meet other Categories” tests play?
gold_answer: You decide by matching the Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission to the category tests and then applying the “must not meet other Categories” exclusions. Category 2 is triggered when the permission authorises Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), the firm’s dealing activities are not limited in scope in the specified way, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5 [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. Category 3C is triggered when the permission authorises one or more of the listed activities (such as Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, managing a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services) and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5 [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]. So, if the firm meets Category 2 (including the “not limited in scope” condition), it cannot be Category 3C because Category 3C excludes firms that meet Category 2. If it does not meet Category 2, then Category 3C remains possible, but only if it meets the listed-activity requirement and none of the excluded categories apply.
target_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.

question: If an Authorised Person is a clearing member acting between a client and a CCP, what must it do to calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the client, and what must it do to calculate EAD for derivatives and long settlement transactions unless it has permission to use an internal model?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person acts as a clearing member and, in that role, is an intermediary between a client and a CCP, it must calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the client using the required approach, and it must also take into account the relevant provisions for any Collateral posted by the client, where applicable [#SRC:57fed3b7-e493-4c49-9c2d-c8c8194bbac8]. Separately, for Derivative transactions (both OTC and exchange-traded) and for long settlement transactions, it must calculate the exposure at default (EAD) in accordance with the section that sets out the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR) [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]. The only stated exception is where the Authorised Person has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model; in that case, the requirement to calculate EAD under that standardised section does not apply [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]. Read together, the clearing-member obligation to calculate Credit RWA for client Trade Exposure relies on having an EAD calculation for the relevant derivatives and long settlement transactions, while also reflecting any client-posted collateral where applicable [#SRC:57fed3b7-e493-4c49-9c2d-c8c8194bbac8].
source_text: Trade Exposure of a clearing member to a client. Where an Authorised Person acts as a clearing member, and in that capacity, acts as an intermediary between a client and a CCP, it must calculate Credit RWA in respect of its Trade Exposure to the client in accordance with Rule A4.6.14, together with App5 and relevant provisions of Section 4.13 in respect of any Collateral posted by the client, if applicable.
target_text: Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). The exposure at default (EAD) of Derivative transactions (OTC and exchange-traded) and long settlement transactions must be calculated in accordance with this Section unless the Authorised Person has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model.

question: Can the Investigator go into a business to inspect and copy documents, and can the Investigator force someone to allow that by sending a written notice? If so, who can get the notice and when can the entry happen?
gold_answer: Yes. The source gives the Investigator permission to enter business premises to inspect and copy documents, but it ties that power to the investigation by limiting it to documents that are relevant for the purposes of the investigation [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767]. The target adds how the Investigator can make that access happen in practice: the Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to permit the Investigator to enter that person’s business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy documents on the premises [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Putting both together, the Investigator can (1) enter premises to inspect/copy documents for the investigation, and (2) use a written notice to require permission to enter from a wide range of people, not just the Person Under Investigation. The timing condition in the target is that entry is during normal business hours, while the source condition is that the documents inspected and copied must be relevant to the investigation.
source_text: Power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents . Section 206(1)(e) of FSMR permits the Investigator to enter business premises for the purpose of inspecting and copying any documents where relevant for the purposes of the investigation.

question: If a Listed Entity/Reporting Entity has to report each year on compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, what does the Listed Entity have to say in its annual financial report about whether it adopted the APP 4 standards, what it did if it did not fully adopt them, and what the Directors think about the effectiveness of its governance framework?
gold_answer: Listed Entities/Reporting Entities are required to provide annual reporting on their compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd]. When the annual financial report obligations apply, the Listed Entity must use its annual financial report to cover three core points: first, it must state whether it has adopted the best practice standards in APP 4 (the Corporate Governance Principles). Second, if those standards were not fully adopted or were only partially adopted, it must explain why that happened and describe what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the relevant standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. Third, the annual financial report must include a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Listed Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, and that statement must be supported by information and assumptions, with qualifications included if necessary [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. These requirements ensure the annual compliance report is not just a declaration, but also explains gaps and governance oversight.
source_text: Note that Listed Entities/Reporting Entities are also required to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of their compliance with Corporate Governance Principles.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to hold Client Money, what must it do each year about the Client Money Auditor's Report, and what must it make sure the Auditor says in the report about Client Money and controls as at the audited statement of financial position date?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business has a Financial Service Permission that entitles it to hold Client Money, it must arrange for a Client Money Auditor’s Report to be submitted to the Regulator every year [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600]. When it is procuring the production of that report, the Authorised Person must also ensure an Auditor includes specific statements tied to the date the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]. These include the amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in accordance with COBS Chapter 14, and whether the Authorised Person maintained systems and controls throughout the year to comply with the relevant COBS Chapter 14 provisions. The Auditor must also state whether controls keep Client Money identifiable and secure at all times, whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met, and whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated in Client Accounts for individual Clients. If applicable, the Auditor must address whether the appropriate amount of Client Money was held and controlled at the statement date, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, and whether there were any material discrepancies in Client Money reconciliation [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17].
source_text: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money must also arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis in accordance with GEN 6.6.6.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, what does it still have to include in that first disclosure, and what does it need to do in a later update so it can avoid repeating the same detailed information?
gold_answer: In the first disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, the Mining Reporting Entity must include the required elements for a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1: all material economic assumptions employed, plus (if it considers those assumptions commercially sensitive) a statement that they are commercially sensitive and an explanation of the methodology used to determine them, as well as all other material assumptions utilised [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. It must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3 [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Once that compliant disclosure has been made, a later disclosure about forecast financial information derived from a Production Target does not need to repeat the information in Rule 11.9.2, but only if it references the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.9.2 and includes a confirmation that all material assumptions from the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. Depending on whether the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must also include an equally prominent and proximate statement of the specified type [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: When the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, may the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User agree in writing that the regime governing charges for information will not apply, and how does that interact with their ability to agree charges for information requested by the Payment Service User that is extra, more frequent, or sent via a different communication method than the Framework Contract specifies?
gold_answer: Yes. Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider are permitted to agree in writing that the specific Rules dealing with charges for information do not apply, meaning they can contract out of that default rule set for this topic [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. Separately, the framework also permits the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User to agree on charges for information provided at the Payment Service User’s request when the information falls into defined categories: it is additional to what must otherwise be provided or made available, it is provided more frequently than specified, or it is transmitted using a means of communication other than those specified in the Framework Contract [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7]. Read together, the parties can (i) rely on the permission to agree charges for these types of requested information, and (ii) if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, additionally agree in writing that the default Rules on charges for information are disapplied, leaving the charging approach to their written agreement within the overall contractual arrangement.
target_text:
The Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User may agree on charges for any information which is provided at the request of the Payment Service User where such information is:
(a)	additional to the information required to be provided or made available by Section 19.2;
(b)	provided more frequently than is specified in Section 19.2; or
(c)	transmitted by means of communication other than those specified in the Framework Contract.

question: When a person is making an Offer of a Unit, how is the scope of this Chapter and its related Rules limited, and how does that exclusion align with the treatment of Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds under the Rulebook’s prospectus content and structure requirements?
gold_answer: Where a person is making an Offer of a Unit, the scope of the regime is expressly narrowed so that the provisions in the Chapter and any Rules made for the purposes of that Chapter do not apply to that person in relation to that activity [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]. This exclusion is consistent with the separate treatment of Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds under the Rulebook: the prospectus requirements on content and structure in chapter 4 of the Rulebook are stated not to apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds, and instead the prospectus requirements that do apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are located in the Fund Rules [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94]. Read together, the passages indicate that, for Unit-related offers, the general Chapter-based framework and the general chapter 4 prospectus content/structure framework are both disapplied in their respective ways, with the applicable prospectus obligations for Offers of Units of Funds being redirected to the Fund Rules rather than the general Rulebook chapter 4 requirements [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] and with the Chapter itself not applying to the person for the act of making the Offer of a Unit [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a].
source_text: The Prospectus requirements including content and structure in chapter 4 of this Rulebook do not apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds. Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules. Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of this Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses.
target_text: The provisions in this Chapter and the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter shall not apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s forecast financial information for an operating mine comes from a Production Target that is wholly based on Ore Reserves (or Ore Reserves plus Measured Mineral Resources, and any Indicated Mineral Resources are not what makes the project viable), what does it still have to include in its disclosure about assumptions and the Production Target itself?
gold_answer: If the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based on Ore Reserves, or on the permitted combinations involving Measured Mineral Resources (and Indicated Mineral Resources only where they are not the determining factor in project viability), then the SOURCE states that a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with the particular compliance requirement identified there [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7]. However, when the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure pursuant to the TARGET provision, that disclosure must still contain specific content: it must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information; if the Mining Reporting Entity considers those material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine them; and it must include all other material assumptions utilised [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In addition, the disclosure must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including the information referenced as being contained with it) [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_text:
A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 where the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based on:
(1)	Ore Reserves;
(2)	a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or
(3)	a combination of Ore Reserves; and
(a)	Measured Mineral Resources; and/or
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: If an ADGM Branch is failing (or likely to fail) and the Non-ADGM Institution is under a Foreign Resolution Action, when is the Regulator allowed to take Resolution Action for the ADGM Branch, and when could the Regulator refuse to recognise that Foreign Resolution Action in a way that matters to this decision?
gold_answer: The Regulator may take a Resolution Action in respect of an ADGM Branch only if it is satisfied that several conditions are met: the ADGM Branch is failing or likely to fail; given the timing and other relevant circumstances, it is not reasonably likely that any action by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or the Non-ADGM Institution will prevent that failure; using a Resolution Tool is in the public interest; and the Non-ADGM Institution is either not subject (and not likely soon to be subject) to any Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings, or it is subject to Foreign Resolution Action and a specified circumstance applies in respect of the Non-ADGM Institution [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726]. Separately, even where there is a Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may refuse to recognise it (in whole or in part) if it is satisfied that one or more listed concerns apply—such as harm to financial stability in the ADGM, Resolution Conditions not being met, ADGM Branch action not being necessary to achieve Resolution Objectives, worse treatment of ADGM creditors compared with creditors in the non-ADGM jurisdiction, or material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba].
source_text:
A Resolution Action may be taken in respect of an ADGM Branch only if the Regulator is satisfied that the following conditions are met—
(a)	the ADGM Branch is failing or is likely to fail;
(b)	having regard to timing and other relevant circumstances, it is not reasonably likely that any action will be taken by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution that will prevent the failure or likely failure of the ADGM Branch or Non-ADGM Institution;
(c)	the application of a Resolution Tool is in the public interest; and
(d)	the Non-ADGM Institution is—
(i)	not subject to, and not likely in a reasonable timeframe to be subject to, any Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings; or
(ii)	subject to Foreign Resolution Action, and one of the circumstances referred to in section 78(2) applies in respect of the Non-ADGM Institution.

question: If an Authorised Person is using the FCCA and has eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, what must it calculate for the exposure and what inputs (including haircuts and currency mismatch) must it use, and how is that result then used in the credit risk weighted exposure amount?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person using the FCCA that has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement must calculate an adjusted exposure amount called E* under the applicable Rules, and then substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the relevant CR Exposure [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de]. For collateralised transactions in scope of the haircut method—meaning the transaction is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement or a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, and it is not an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction—the Authorised Person must calculate E* using the stated formula under the FCCA with standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949]. To do this, it must identify E as the fair value of the Exposure, apply the Exposure haircut (HE), identify C as the fair value of eligible financial Collateral received, apply the Collateral haircut (HC) (or a weighted sum if the Collateral is a basket), and apply the currency mismatch haircut (HFX) where relevant. The formula also requires that E* cannot be negative (it is floored at zero).
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.

question: An Authorised Person must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets when working out CET1 Capital. How can the Authorised Person reduce the amount it deducts if there is a deferred tax liability linked to those assets, or if it can use some of the pension fund assets after giving advance notice to the Regulator?
gold_answer: In the CET1 Capital calculation, an Authorised Person is required to deduct defined benefit pension fund assets as one of the specified CET1 deductions [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. But the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets that must be deducted is not necessarily the gross asset amount: it must be reduced by certain amounts that are directly tied to those pension fund assets [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada]. One reduction is for any associated deferred tax liability, but only to the extent that the liability could be extinguished if the pension fund assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada]. A second reduction is available for assets in the defined benefit pension fund that the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use, provided it has given the Regulator adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada]. Any assets used to reduce the deduction must then receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada].
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - defined benefit pension fund assets. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(d), the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted from CET1 Capital must be reduced by the following:
(a)	the amount of any associated deferred tax liability which could be extinguished if the assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and
(b)	the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund which the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use where the Authorised Person has provided adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets to the Regulator. Those assets used to reduce the amount to be deducted must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules.

question: In preparing the annual report/annual financial report, what must the Board of Directors/Directors state about the effectiveness of the entity’s Corporate Governance framework, and how must that statement be supported and framed in relation to adoption of the Corporate Governance Principles and any non-adoption or partial adoption of best practice standards?
gold_answer: Both regimes require the annual report package to contain an express Directors-level assessment of the Corporate Governance framework’s effectiveness, supported by appropriate context and evidence. Under the SOURCE obligation, the annual report must include a statement by the Board of Directors stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the relevant governance outcome and promoting compliance with the Principles, and that statement must be accompanied by supporting information and assumptions, with qualifications if necessary [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca]. Under the TARGET obligation, the annual financial report of a Listed Entity must state whether the Corporate Governance Principles have been adopted; if not fully or only partially adopted, it must explain why and describe what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent of the gap; and it must also include a statement by Directors on whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance, again with supporting information and assumptions and qualifications if necessary [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. Practically, the Directors’ effectiveness statement should be consistent with, and informed by, the adoption/disclosure narrative and any described remediation actions.
source_text: General. The annual report required under Rule 9.2.10 must include a statement by the Board of Directors (the "Board"), stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR and promoting compliance with the Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary. As the Principles are the core of the Corporate Governance framework, the way in which they are applied should be the central question for the Board as it determines how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs under its directorship in accordance with the letter and spirit of the applicable requirements including the Principles and the standards.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: When considering an Application for Listing, to what extent is the Regulator permitted to attach, later change, or remove conditions or restrictions relating to the admission of Securities to the Official List, and how does that permission align with the Regulator’s power described in the FSMR?
gold_answer: Across both passages, the Regulator is expressly permitted to manage the admission of Securities to the Official List by imposing conditions or restrictions and then subsequently adjusting that regulatory treatment. The SOURCE states that, under the FSMR, the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List and may also vary or withdraw those conditions or restrictions, establishing the baseline permission and its ongoing nature [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226]. The TARGET confirms the same permission in the specific context of the Regulator’s decision-making on an Application for Listing, listing as an available action the ability to impose conditions or restrictions (and to vary or withdraw them) in respect of admission to the Official List, and indicating that this is exercisable in the circumstances specified in a further subsection [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]. Read together, the Regulator’s permission covers (i) initial imposition at admission, and (ii) later variation or withdrawal, with the TARGET situating that permission within the application/decision framework.
source_text: Under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR, the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions.
target_text:
The Regulator may—
(a)	refuse an Application for Listing; or
(b)	impose conditions or restrictions, in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions;
in the circumstances specified in subsection ‎(2).

question: If there is no written agreement to change what goes into the Governing Contract, how should a Third Party Provider meet the rule that the Customer must get the required information before being bound?
gold_answer: Without a written agreement changing the contract content, the Third Party Provider must do two connected things. The Third Party Provider must provide the Customer with the required information before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]. At the same time, the Governing Contract must contain the specified information unless otherwise agreed in writing [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. That means the contract should set out, among other items, the Third Party Provider’s identity and ADGM contact details, its regulator and Financial Service Permission, the key features and limits of the Third Party Services, what the Customer must provide and how consent works for a Third Party Transaction, timing and maximum service timeframes, all charges and any relevant exchange rate approach, agreed communication methods and information frequency, safeguards and corrective steps (including reporting periods and fraud/security contact procedures), how changes and termination will operate, and available redress (courts/law and any alternative dispute resolution). Delivering these disclosures to the Customer before they are bound, and ensuring they appear in the contract, satisfies both requirements.
source_text:
A Third Party Provider must provide a Customer the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract.
Information provision during period of the Governing Contract

question: When can an Authorised Person give a Related Person credit on better terms than it gives to non-Related Persons, and what must the Credit Risk policy do to manage conflicts of interest and approvals in that situation?
gold_answer: The Credit Risk policy must manage conflicts of interest around providing and managing credit by setting out adequate procedures, including measures to prevent any Person who directly or indirectly benefits from the credit from being part of the process of granting or managing that credit [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]. It must also address Related Person transactions by generally prohibiting Exposures to Related Persons on more favourable terms than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, and by requiring that certain higher-risk or higher-amount Exposures (and any write-offs) be subject to prior written approval by the firm’s Governing Body or its delegate, with beneficiaries excluded from the approval process [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]. However, the prohibition on more favourable terms does not apply if the credit is provided under an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person, is approved by the Governing Body or its delegate, and clearly sets out the terms, conditions, and limits for such credit [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91]. That Employee credit policy must also include mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance and immediate reporting of deviations or breaches to the Governing Body or its delegate for timely action [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91].
source_text:
Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must:
(a)	set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit;
(b)	subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and
(c)	if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that:
(i)	require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and
(ii)	exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, what must it say about the Competent Person(s), and what consent must it have before publishing the information in that form?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity must do two things in parallel: include required Competent Person(s) statements in the disclosure and ensure the disclosure is issued only with the required written consent on how the information is presented. On the content side, the disclosure must state that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). It must also state, for each Competent Person, whether they are an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party; if they are not, the disclosure must name the Competent Person’s employer. The disclosure must further state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]. On the permission side, where the disclosure includes Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves (and supporting information), it must only be made with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) regarding the form and context in which the information is presented [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8].
source_text: Competent Persons . The disclosure made in Rule 11.12.1 must only be made with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: In the context of an investigation, when may the Investigator compel attendance at an interview and questioning, and does that authority extend beyond the Person Under Investigation to other individuals regardless of any connection to that person, provided the requirement is issued by written notice?
gold_answer: Across the two provisions, the Investigator is permitted to compel a person to attend an interview and answer questions as part of an investigation, and the mechanism and scope are clarified. The SOURCE establishes the core investigative permission: the Investigator has the power to require a person (described as the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of an investigation [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf]. The TARGET then specifies how and to whom that power may be directed: the Investigator may do so by written notice, and the notice may be addressed either to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, expressly including persons who are not connected to the Person Under Investigation [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Read together, the Investigator’s permission is not limited to the subject of the investigation; it can reach third parties, and it is exercisable through a written notice that can require attendance at a specified time and place and answering questions. This combined reading supports compliance planning for both primary subjects and potential third-party interviewees.
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . Under section 206(1)(a) of FSMR, the Investigator has the power to require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of an investigation.

question: How should an Authorised Person determine whether its Financial Services Permission places it in Category 2 versus Category 3C, where it is authorised for Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal) and also has permissions that could include Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody (other than for a Fund), Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services? In particular, how do the respective exclusion tests against other Categories and the scope limitation condition for dealing affect the classification outcome?
gold_answer: To classify an Authorised Person, start with what its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on and then apply the category-specific conditions and exclusions. Category 2 applies where the permission authorises Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), the dealing activities are not limited in scope in the specified way, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5 [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. By contrast, Category 3C applies where the permission authorises one or more of the listed activities (including Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, managing a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services) and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5 [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]. Accordingly, if the firm satisfies the Category 2 conditions, it is excluded from Category 3C by Category 3C’s express “does not meet Category 2” requirement; if it does not satisfy Category 2 (including because the dealing scope condition is not met), it may fall within Category 3C if it meets the listed-activity limb and the broader exclusion set.
target_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.

question: If a person’s trades or orders could mislead the market about supply, demand, or price, or could push the price to an artificial level, must they avoid doing this unless they can show they acted for legitimate reasons and followed an Accepted Market Practice on that market?
gold_answer: The target text describes a prohibited type of Behaviour: effecting transactions or orders to trade in a way that is not for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, where the result is (or is likely to be) a false or misleading impression about supply, demand, or price, or where it secures an abnormal or artificial price level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. The source text provides the key condition that can justify the conduct: if a person establishes that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice, then they meet the legitimacy-and-conformity standard referenced in the target [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73]. Put simply, the prohibition is triggered when the trading is done “otherwise than” for legitimate reasons and accepted practice and has the misleading/artificial effects described; the permission concept is that the person can rely on legitimate reasons plus conformity with an Accepted Market Practice, but only if they can establish those points.
source_text: Market Practice. If a person establishes that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice (see section 92(4)).
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity wants to publish forecast financial information derived from a Production Target again later, what is it allowed to link that forecast to (its holdings or a project), and what must it include so it can leave out the extra supporting details?
gold_answer: Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to a Mining Reporting Entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s) [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]. If the Mining Reporting Entity has already made an earlier disclosure of that kind of forecast financial information that complied with the required content, then a later disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target does not need to repeat the otherwise required supporting information, but only if it meets the stated conditions [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. The later disclosure must point back to the earlier compliant disclosure and must confirm that all the material assumptions used in the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. Also, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement about the disclosed forecast financial information; and if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, it must include a similarly prominent and proximate statement tailored to that situation [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).
