question: If the Regulator decides to approve an Application for Listing, does it have to tell the Applicant in writing, and is this tied to the decision on admission of Securities to the Official List?
gold_answer: Yes. The Regulator has an obligation to notify the Applicant in writing of its decision in relation to the application for admission of Securities to the Official List [#SRC:c1f2bce6-f17b-456d-b187-9b5c3becc00e]. In addition, when the Regulator’s decision is to grant an Application for Listing, it must give the Applicant written notice of its decision [#TGT:f042ba18-df6f-45eb-92c9-0bd804f9ef7c]. Taken together, these requirements mean that once the Regulator has decided the outcome of the relevant application process, the Applicant must receive a written notice communicating that decision, and this includes the scenario where the application is granted. The key compliance point is that the communication must be in writing, must come from the Regulator, and must be provided to the Applicant as the formal notification of the decision connected to admission/listing on the Official List.
source_text: Under section 52(3) of the FSMR, the Regulator will notify the Applicant in writing of its decision in relation to the application for admission of Securities to the Official List.
target_text: If the Regulator decides to grant an Application for Listing, it must give the Applicant written notice of its decision.

question: When a decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator, or Rules made by the Regulator, may affect a person’s rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect that person’s interests, is that person permitted to refer the matter to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review, and are any categories of decisions excluded from referral under the broader framework described?
gold_answer: Yes. Where a decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator, or Rules made by the Regulator, may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect that person’s interests, that person may refer the decision to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23]. The broader framework described alongside this permission indicates that the referral right is framed to cover decisions that may affect rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect interests, but it also notes an exclusion for operational decisions from the set of decisions that may be referred for a full merits review [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. In addition, the framework explains that certain other decisions—specifically including decisions such as the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers—may also be referable to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review even where they are not subject to the Part 21 procedure [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. Taken together, the permission to refer in the Regulations operates for affected persons, while the broader description clarifies both an operational-decision carve-out and that some additional non‑Part 21 decisions may still be referable.
source_text: Section 225(1) of FSMR provides that all of our decisions that may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person (except operational decisions) may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review. FSMR also specifies that certain other decisions, not subject to the Part 21 procedure, may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review (e.g., exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers).
target_text: Any decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator or Rules made by the Regulator which may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person, may be referred by that person to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review .

question: If someone is listed in the Rules made by the Regulator as liable for a Prospectus, do they still have to pay compensation for a misleading statement or missing required information when the buyer bought the Securities knowing the statement was wrong or knowing what was left out (or changed) or knowing about a new matter or inaccuracy?
gold_answer: Under the Prospectus compensation rule, any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to a person who acquired the Securities covered by that Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement, or because it omitted a material matter that was required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. But there is an important limitation: a Person does not incur liability where the person who incurred the loss acquired the Securities with knowledge that the statement was false, misleading, or deceptive, or with knowledge of the omitted matter (or the change), or with knowledge of the new matter or inaccuracy [#SRC:4ee654af-eec8-49f1-8813-6fb847d3eecb]. Put simply, even if the Prospectus has a misleading statement or a missing required item, the compensation obligation does not apply against that Person when the buyer purchased while already knowing the relevant problem (falsehood, omission/change, or new matter/inaccuracy) that is tied to the claimed loss.
source_text:
A Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if the Person incurring the loss acquired the Securities in question with knowledge:
(a)	that the statement was false, misleading, or deceptive;
(b)	of the omitted matter or of the change; or
(c)	of the new matter or inaccuracy.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: If an Authorised Person runs periodic stress tests on securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, what must the tests cover to capture the firm-wide effects in a stressed market (including other risks and pipeline deals that might fail) and to check whether the firm can still use securitisation for CRM or liquidity?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must carry out periodic stress tests for its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, and the testing must include checking its future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa]. To make those stress tests meaningful, the firm should structure them to consider the firm wide impact of the securitisation activities and related Exposures in stressed market conditions, and to identify the implications for other sources of risk (so the analysis is not limited to the securitisation book in isolation) [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]. The tests should also cover both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, because stressed conditions can create a risk that pipeline transactions are not completed, which can change the firm’s exposure profile and its ability to rely on securitisation plans [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]. In practice, the required stress testing therefore needs to be periodic, forward-looking, and broad enough to connect firm-wide risk impacts with the firm’s continued capacity to use securitisation for CRM or liquidity under stress [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97].
source_text: The periodic stress testing in relation to securitisation activities referred to in Rule 4.14.5 should consider the firm wide impact of those activities and Exposures in stressed market conditions and the implications for other sources of risk. Such stress tests should include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, as there is a risk of the pipeline transactions not being completed in a stressed market scenario.
target_text: Systems and controls for the use of securitisations. An Authorised Person must conduct periodic stress tests in relation to its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, including testing of future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes.

question: In what situations can the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund skip hiring a third party to attest compliance, even though it normally must get ongoing and at least annual attestation for the part of Eligible Green Fund Property invested in taxonomy-aligned assets?
gold_answer: Normally, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but that requirement is targeted: it applies only to the portion of Eligible Green Fund Property invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] The Fund Manager can skip appointing a third party under the Alternative Attestation Requirement in two cases. First, if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund, the Fund Manager may elect to provide the attestation itself; in that case, the Fund Manager is not required to appoint a third party even though an attestation is still being provided. Second, if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, then an attestation is not required at all. These alternatives operate as exceptions to the general third-party appointment approach and determine whether the Fund Manager must engage an external attester or can rely on self-attestation or no attestation, depending on the Fund’s status and asset composition. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]
source_text: The Green Fund Attestation Requirement. Subject to Rule 20.2.9, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually.  This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎20.2.3(a). This is referred to as the “Green Fund Attestation Requirement”.
target_text:
Alternative Attestation Requirement. The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund is not required to appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement if:
(a)	the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself; or
(b)	all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark pursuant to Rule ‎20.2.3(b), in which event an attestation is not required.

question: How must an Authorised Person determine and then continuously hold the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital, specifically where the buffer is the Countercyclical Capital Buffer derived from the Total Risk Exposure Amount and the weighted average of applicable jurisdictional buffer rates for private sector credit exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person has two linked obligations: it must first compute the relevant buffer as a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital, and it must then ensure that the required buffer amount is actually maintained as CET1 Capital on an ongoing basis. The calculation step requires the Authorised Person to determine a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures are located [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. Once that required buffer amount has been calculated, the Authorised Person must maintain that required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, meaning the obligation is continuous rather than point-in-time compliance [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]. Read together, the framework requires both a prescribed method to quantify the countercyclical buffer and a standing requirement to hold the resulting amount in CET1 Capital without interruption.
source_text: An Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, as calculated in accordance with Rule 3.18.4.
target_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, what does it have to put in its forecast financial disclosure, and what else must it tell investors so they can understand how it calculated and reported its Ore Reserves estimates?
gold_answer: For forecast financial information, a Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure must cover the assumptions used to determine that forecast, including all material economic assumptions employed; if the Mining Reporting Entity considers those material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology it used to determine the material economic assumptions, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. When the same Mining Reporting Entity is reporting estimates of Ore Reserves and is relying on the relevant guidance, it must again make a statement that its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, should explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive, and must still disclose enough information for investors to understand the methodology used to determine the relevant factors and assumptions and the basis on which it is reporting the Ore Reserves estimates [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80]. Where the numbers themselves are sensitive, the Ore Reserves disclosure can be narrative rather than numerical, but it must remain sufficient for investor understanding.
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
ORE RESERVES. In such cases, however, where a Mining Reporting Entity relies on the guidance set out in Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), it:

a)	must make a statement to the effect that its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive;

b)	should explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive; and

c)	must disclose sufficient information (possibly in narrative rather than numerical form, where the numbers are commercially sensitive) in order for investors to understand the methodology it has used to determine these factors and assumptions, and the basis on which it is reporting the estimates of Ore Reserves.

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, how must it determine the collateralised and uncollateralised portions for CRM recognition, and what minimum or alternative CRW must it apply to the collateralised portion when the CRW derived from treating the Collateral as a direct Exposure would otherwise fall below 20%?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, it is permitted to recognise CRM by splitting the Exposure into a collateralised portion equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral and an uncollateralised portion equal to the CR Exposure amount net of that latest fair value, and then applying the CRW for the collateralised portion as if it had a direct Exposure to the Collateral while applying the obligor’s CRW to the uncollateralised portion [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb]. However, if the CRW that results from that “direct Exposure to the Collateral” approach for the collateralised portion is less than 20%, the Authorised Person must apply a 20% CRW to the collateralised portion, unless one of the specified exceptions applies [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]. Those exceptions allow lower CRWs for certain qualifying SFTs depending on whether the Counterparty is a core market participant, and for certain OTC Derivative transactions subject to daily mark to market with specified collateral types and no currency mismatch, as well as for certain no-currency-mismatch transactions involving cash on Deposit or specified 0% risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures (with a 20% discount condition for the latter).
source_text:
Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows:
(a) 	break down the Exposure into -
(i) 	a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and
(ii) 	an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral;
and
(b) 	for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use:
(i) 	for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and
(ii) 	for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already disclosed material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation with all required details, when can it make a later disclosure about those estimates without repeating all the details, and what does it still have to say clearly next to the estimates?
gold_answer: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it must include specific information in the disclosure, including a clear statement placed prominently and close to the estimates explaining that they are Non-Equivalent Estimates, not reported under a Mining Reporting Standard, not yet classified by a Competent Person as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and may never become reportable as such, plus other required supporting items (for example, sources/dates, relevance, reliability, summaries of work and assumptions, and verification work, timing and funding) [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. But if the Mining Reporting Entity has already made an earlier disclosure of those Non-Equivalent Estimates that complied with those requirements, a later disclosure about the same estimates does not need to repeat the required information as long as it (1) points back to the earlier compliant disclosure, (2) confirms the earlier information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting reliability/interpretation or the entity’s ability to verify the estimates under a Mining Reporting Standard, and (3) still includes an equally prominent and proximate statement about the estimates covering the same key matters as the original prominent statement requirement [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4].
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: When an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 experiences a drop in its Capital Resources to below the specified buffer relative to its Capital Requirement, what notifications must it make to the Regulator, how quickly must it act, and what additional formality is required beyond the initial notification?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4, the trigger event is its Capital Resources falling below 120% of its Capital Requirement. When that threshold is breached, it must notify the Regulator immediately, reflecting the urgency of the obligation and the expectation that the Regulator is informed without delay once the shortfall occurs [#SRC:c08e86ed-69f1-4d9f-81bf-af5206de7e41]. In addition to making the immediate notification, the Authorised Person must also confirm the notification in writing, meaning the communication is not complete with only an immediate alert and must be followed by a written confirmation to the Regulator [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]. The combined requirements therefore impose both (i) a timing requirement (immediate notification upon the threshold breach) and (ii) a documentation/form requirement (written confirmation), each tied to the same capital-resources trigger and the same specified categories of Authorised Person.
source_text: An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement, in accordance with Rule 3.20.2.
target_text: Notifications to the Regulator. An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately and confirm in writing if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement.

question: In the context where certain notification requirements applicable to Recognised Investment Exchanges are stated to apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets), what must a Recognised Body notify the Regulator about when its Governing Body delegates Regulatory Functions to a standing committee, and how quickly must that notification be made?
gold_answer: When an MTF (using Virtual Assets) is brought within the scope of the notification regime described as applying to Recognised Investment Exchanges, those notification and information requirements operate as additional requirements for that MTF, alongside any other applicable notification requirements identified in the same guidance context [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]. Within that framework, a Recognised Body must notify the Regulator, in the circumstances noted, about governance arrangements involving standing committees where the Governing Body delegates any of its Regulatory Functions to a standing committee, or appoints a standing committee to manage or oversee the carrying out of any of the Recognised Body’s Regulatory Functions. The timing requirement for that notification is “as soon as practicable.” The information that must be provided with the notification is (a) the names of the members of that standing committee and (b) the terms of reference of that standing committee, including a description of any powers delegated to the committee and any conditions or limitations placed on the exercise of those powers [#TGT:4089ddbd-ee76-45ed-a673-48384237c975].
source_text:
MULTILATERAL TRADING FACILITIES AND VIRTUAL ASSETS
Guidance in relation to Applicable Rules
COBS Rule 17.7.4 specifies that certain notification requirements applicable to Recognised Investment Exchanges under MIR Rules 5.1, 5.3 and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1 apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets). These are additional requirements applicable to MTFs using Virtual Assets. MTFs using Virtual Assets will also need to comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those set out in paragraph 29 of this Guidance in relation to the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets.

(c) where the Recognised Body proposes to close an MTF/OTF, the name of that MTF/OTF.

question: If an Authorised Person does not meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, what must it do to work out the maximum distributable amount, and what two inputs must it multiply (profits and a quartile-based factor) before it can move forward with restricted distributions or payments?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must calculate the maximum distributable amount as a required step tied to restrictions on distributions and certain payments [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. To determine that amount, the method requires multiplying a specified profit total by a factor. The profit total is the total of interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital and that accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any relevant actions referenced in the calculation framework [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. The factor is then chosen based on where the Authorised Person’s CET1 Capital (that is not used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement) falls within the quartiles of the Combined Buffer Requirement: 0 in the first quartile, 0.2 in the second, 0.4 in the third, and 0.6 in the fourth [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. This multiplication-based determination is the required way to compute the maximum distributable amount in the circumstances described [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].
target_text:
Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and
(b)	ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7:
(i)	make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: When the Prospectus for a Passported Fund is amended or replaced and the Regulator must be notified, what must be sent with the notification, and what is the latest deadline for sending it once the relevant party knows about the change?
gold_answer: If the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund is amended or replaced, this is one of the events that triggers a requirement to notify the Regulator as soon as practicable and, in any case, no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. The notification must also meet minimum submission and information standards. It must be made in the prescribed form that the Regulator may direct from time to time, and it must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event—here, the nature of the Prospectus change—so the Regulator has an adequate description of what occurred [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]. In addition, because the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, the notification must include a copy of the new Prospectus, ensuring the Regulator receives the updated disclosure document together with the notice and supporting detail [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].
source_text: The notification referred to in Rule 6.6.2 must be in such prescribed form as the Regulator may direct from time to time.  At a minimum, the notification must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event and (where the Prospectus has been amended or replaced) a copy of the new Prospectus.

question: Where an Applicant’s written application must state the address of the Remote Members registered office and head office in its home jurisdiction, how does that information connect to the Remote Member Requirements concerning the Remote Member’s place of business and office location relative to the ADGM?
gold_answer: The written application must include the address of the Remote Members registered office and head office in its home jurisdiction, which is a required data point for the Applicant’s submission and is part of the minimum content that must be provided in writing [#SRC:9820bf55-9b39-42c8-8471-04d83bc34f82]. This information directly supports assessment against the Remote Member Requirements that define the Remote Member’s geographic and establishment criteria: the Remote Member must carry on business in a jurisdiction other than the ADGM and must have its head office and registered office outside the ADGM [#TGT:1c380817-662e-4a9b-ab9d-3bc555c5b20d]. By requiring the applicant to specify the registered office and head office addresses in the home jurisdiction, the application provides the factual basis to evidence that the Remote Member’s offices are not located in the ADGM and that it operates from another jurisdiction, as required by the definition of the Remote Member Requirements [#SRC:9820bf55-9b39-42c8-8471-04d83bc34f82] [#TGT:1c380817-662e-4a9b-ab9d-3bc555c5b20d]. In addition, because the application must also explain how the Applicant will satisfy the Remote Member Requirements, the office-location information is not merely descriptive; it is part of demonstrating compliance with the defined condition that the Remote Member’s business presence and offices remain outside the ADGM while it seeks membership of the specified Recognised Body [#SRC:9820bf55-9b39-42c8-8471-04d83bc34f82] [#TGT:1c380817-662e-4a9b-ab9d-3bc555c5b20d].

question: If a trader quickly takes more than 90% of the physical crude oil inventory behind a contract and then sells out during the final settlement window at rising prices, when does that become the kind of Behaviour defined as trading without legitimate reasons and not following Accepted Market Practices—especially if it makes supply/demand look different or pushes prices to an abnormal level?
gold_answer: In the example, the Regulator describes an abusive squeeze where, during a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract, fails to offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate, and then unwinds the position in the Exchange’s final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the market and causing an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7]. The definition to apply asks whether the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade other than for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, and whether those trades/orders either (a) give or are likely to give a false or misleading impression about supply, demand, or price, or (b) secure the price at an abnormal or artificial level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. Practically, you would connect the inventory dominance, refusal to lend, and settlement-window unwind to the definition’s focus on misleading impressions and abnormal/artificial pricing outcomes.
source_text:
Abusive squeezes. The following are specific examples of an abusive squeeze that, in the Regulator's view, may contravene section 92 (4)(b):
(a)	during the course of a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up a position of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract.  The trader fails to Offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate.  The trader then unwinds his position in the Exchange's final settlement window  at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the crude oil market.  His conduct causes an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery; and
(b)	a trader with a long position in bond futures, buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and either refuses to re-lend these bonds or will only lend them to parties he believes will not re-lend to the market.  His purpose is to position the price at which persons with short positions have to deliver to satisfy their obligations at a materially higher level, making him a profit on his position.
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: In the quarterly report, how often does a Mining Production Reporting Entity have to provide the Summary of Reserves and Resources (or where can it be included instead), and when that Summary is disclosed what table must a Mining Reporting Entity include and how recent must its date be?
gold_answer: In its quarterly reporting, a Mining Production Reporting Entity must include the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months, unless the Summary is included in the Mining Reporting Entity’s annual report instead; the quarterly report must also indicate when the prior and next such Summary disclosure was and will be made. This is a required element of the quarterly report that is disclosed for each quarter of the financial year and covers the Mining Production Reporting Entity and all controlled entities on a consolidated basis, if applicable [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b]. When the Summary of Reserves and Resources is actually disclosed, a Mining Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1 within that Summary, and the table must be dated as of a point no earlier than one month before the Summary’s disclosure date [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd]. Practically, this means you must plan the annual cadence through the quarterly process (or the annual report alternative) and also ensure the Summary’s required table is prepared using a sufficiently recent “as of” date relative to when you publish the Summary.
target_text: A Mining Reporting Entity must include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources, a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1, as of a date no earlier than one month prior to the disclosure of the Summary of Reserves and Resources.

question: If the Regulator thinks an auditor or actuary has broken the Regulations and may disqualify them, what does it mean in practice to look at all the circumstances before deciding whether to disqualify and how wide the ban should be (for one entity, or a class of Authorised Persons, Recognised Bodies or Reporting Entities)?
gold_answer: If the Regulator considers an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention, it is permitted to disqualify that person from being the auditor of, or acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity, or a particular class of them [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e]. Before deciding to use that power and before setting how wide the disqualification should be, the Regulator should take into account all the circumstances of the case [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]. Practically, this includes looking at how serious the contravention is and what impact it had; whether the contravention (or any failure to disclose information to the Regulator) has caused or is likely to cause loss to customers, damage the reputation of the ADGM, or increase the risk that a firm, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity could be used for financial crime [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]. The Regulator should also consider any steps the auditor or actuary took to remedy the issue, any relevant disciplinary action by a professional body (and whether it adequately addresses the contravention), and the person’s previous compliance record and prior sanctions, to decide whether a narrow or broader disqualification is justified [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].
target_text: If the Regulator considers that an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify the auditor or actuary from being the auditor of, or (as the case may be), from acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof.

question: For an Authorised Person, how should its categorisation be determined where its Financial Services Permission includes authorisation to Accept Deposits or manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account as a PSIAu, but it is also authorised for activities such as Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account as a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of an express trust, or Providing Money Services? Identify the determinative permissions and the exclusion tests that must be applied to decide whether it falls in Category 1 or Category 3C.
gold_answer: Categorisation turns on which Regulated Activities the Authorised Person is authorised to carry on under its Financial Services Permission and on the relevant exclusion tests. Under the Category 1 definition, an Authorised Person is in Category 1 if its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and it does not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance confirms that this authorisation is determinative even if other Regulated Activities are also authorised [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. By contrast, Category 3C applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises one or more of Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody (other than for a Fund), Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services (as trustee of at least one express trust), or Providing Money Services, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5; the guidance similarly treats those authorisations (and the absence of certain other authorisations) as determinative [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]. Accordingly, if the firm meets the Category 1 trigger and is not Category 5, it is Category 1; Category 3C is only available if the firm does not meet Category 1 (and the other listed categories) while meeting the Category 3C activity trigger.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: If you must calculate the Exposure value for on-balance sheet derivatives as the IFRS balance sheet amount plus an add-on for potential future exposure, how do you then calculate RC for unmargined transactions, including what goes into V and C and how the netting set and collateral are handled?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), you must calculate the Exposure value as the sum of the on-balance sheet value under IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under the specified App 4 rules, so your process needs to capture both the current IFRS amount and the separate add-on component [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]. When those derivative transactions are unmargined and you need RC, you follow the stated RC procedure: compute RC as max{V – C; 0}. In that formula, V is the value of the derivative transactions in the netting set, and the netting set must be constituted in accordance with the referenced netting-set rule. C is the haircut value of the net collateral held, and it must be calculated in accordance with the referenced collateral haircut section [#TGT:7925206c-3c2f-45a8-940b-3cbf102d8e84]. Practically, this means you first identify the correct netting set for the derivatives, determine V for that set, determine the haircut-adjusted net collateral amount C, and then apply the max test so RC cannot be negative.
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text:
Calculation of RC for unmargined transactions. RC for unmargined transactions is calculated in accordance with the following formula:
RC = max{V – C; 0}
where:
V = the value of the derivative transactions in the netting set (constituted in accordance with Rule A4.6.18); and
C = the haircut value of the net collateral held, calculated in accordance with Section A4.3.

question: When a Listed Entity proposes to issue Equity Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme and intends to rely on holder approval to avoid breaching the cap on new issues, what specific information must not be omitted from the notice of meeting, and how does that notice content support the required approval to issue above the calculated maximum?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing, or agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the prescribed 20% Base Amount formula (net of Relevant Issues) unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. Where the proposed issue is under an Employee Incentive Scheme and the Listed Entity is seeking that holder approval as the relevant exception within the prior three-year window, the notice of meeting must include three core disclosures: a summary of the terms of the scheme; the number of Securities issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List (or since the date of the last approval under the relevant approval pathway); and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme following the approval [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113]. These notice elements are the procedural minimum that enables holders of Ordinary Securities to give the approval that is necessary to permit an issue that would otherwise exceed the calculated maximum under the restriction on new issues.
source_text:
An issue of Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme if within three years before the issue date:
(a)	in the case of a scheme established before the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List – a summary of the terms of the scheme and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme were set out in in its Approved Prospectus or documents lodged with the Regulator under Rule 2.4.3; or
(b)	the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities have approved the issue of Equity Securities under the scheme as an exception to Rule 9.7.1.  The notice of meeting must have included:
(i)	a summary of the terms of the scheme;
(ii)	the number of Securities issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List, or the date of the last approval under this Rule; and
(iii)	the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme following the approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: What does a Fund Manager have to tell its auditor to do about auditing the Fund’s financial statements, and what does the Fund Manager have to make sure the Auditor says in the Fund Auditor’s Report?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager must do more than simply appoint an auditor; it must set clear requirements for both the audit and the report. The Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in line with the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB), and it must require the auditor to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on the audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. Then, when the Fund Manager is procuring the production of that Fund Auditor’s Report, it must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements. These cover whether the financial statements were properly prepared using the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, whether they give a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and results for the annual accounting period and at the end of that period, and whether there are problems such as missing accounting records, disagreement between the financial statements and accounting records/returns, or non-compliance with applicable financial reporting standards [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]. The Auditor must also state whether it received all necessary information and explanations, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].
source_text:
Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: For an Authorised Person’s Credit Risk policy addressing conflicts of interest in Related Person transactions, when may the policy permit Providing Credit to a Related Person on more favourable terms than those offered to Persons who are not Related Persons, and what governance, procedural, and monitoring conditions must be met to keep that exception within scope?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person’s Credit Risk policy must include adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person who directly or indirectly benefits from the credit from being involved in granting or managing it, and it must also exclude such beneficiaries from any approval process for relevant Exposures and write-offs [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]. While the policy generally prohibits Exposures to Related Persons on more favourable terms than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, that prohibition is out of scope where the more favourable terms arise under an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person and is approved by the Authorised Person’s Governing Body or the Governing Body’s delegate [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91]. To rely on this exception, the credit policy must clearly set out the terms, conditions, and limits (individual and aggregate) for providing such credit, and it must require adequate mechanisms for ongoing compliance, including immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate upon any deviation or breach for timely and appropriate action [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91].
source_text:
Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must:
(a)	set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit;
(b)	subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and
(c)	if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that:
(i)	require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and
(ii)	exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.

question: What does an Authorised Person have to do to keep its group capital position compliant at all times, and if it falls short, how will the Regulator look at the situation (including any fixes made by the Authorised Person or another regulator) before deciding on enforcement?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to keep its Financial Group Capital Resources at least equal to, or higher than, its Financial Group Capital Requirement at all times, based on the specified methods for calculating each figure [#TGT:b0fe779d-b7f0-48a6-a00d-06a3f3dc8106]. This is a continuous obligation, so the Authorised Person should be able to demonstrate that it monitors and manages its capital position so that resources do not drop below the requirement. If the Authorised Person breaches the relevant rule connected to this requirement, the Regulator will not decide enforcement solely on the fact of the breach; it will take into account the full circumstances of the case when determining what enforcement action, if any, it will take [#SRC:12a7fe75-3ede-4f19-86af-34a1e60cfe3b]. In doing so, the Regulator will consider remedial steps, including steps taken by the Authorised Person itself and steps taken by another regulator. Practically, that means the Authorised Person’s corrective actions and any parallel regulatory remediation can be important context in how the Regulator assesses the breach and whether enforcement is warranted.
source_text: If an Authorised Person breaches Rule 8.3.2, the Regulator will take into account the full circumstances of the case, including any remedial steps taken by another regulator or the Authorised Person, in determining what enforcement action, if any, it will take.
target_text: An Authorised Person must ensure at all times that its Financial Group Capital Resources, as calculated in Rule 8.3.4, are equal to or in excess of its Financial Group Capital Requirement as calculated in Rule 8.3.3.

question: If an Authorised Person is applying to change an existing Financial Services Permission so it can do more Regulated Activities, what fees must it pay to the Regulator, and how do you work out the fee when more than one Regulated Activity is included in the same application?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that applies to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission so it can undertake additional Regulated Activities must pay application fees to the Regulator under the applicable fee provisions [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. When the amendment application covers one or more additional Regulated Activities (or otherwise involves multiple Regulated Activities being applied for at the same time), the fee is not calculated by simply adding only one base fee; instead, the Authorised Person must pay the highest of the relevant application fees for the Regulated Activities included in that application at that time [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. On top of that highest fee, each additional Regulated Activity included in the same application also attracts an extra application fee, which is the lesser of $10,000 or the specific application fee set out in the Rules for that activity [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. In practice, you identify all Regulated Activities being requested in the amendment, pay the highest applicable fee among them, and then add the required incremental fee for each additional activity requested at the same time.
source_text:
Amendment of a Financial Services Permission other than the addition of a Regulated Activity
(a)	Subject to Rule 2.1(c), an Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake additional Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator such application fees as set out in Rule 3.2.1.
(b)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to serve Retail Clients, other than pursuant to Rule 3.20.1, must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
(c)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to conduct Islamic Financial Business must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
(d)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission through the amendment or removal of a condition, other than in accordance with (b) or (c), must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
target_text:
In respect of:
(a)	an Applicant seeking to obtain a Financial Service Permission enabling the Applicant to undertake multiple Regulated Activities; or
(b)	an Authorised Person seeking to amend a Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake one or more additional Regulated Activities.
the Applicant or Authorised Person, as the case may be, must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with the Regulated Activities being applied for at that time.  Each additional Regulated Activity applied for at that time shall incur an additional application fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the application fee specified in these Rules.

question: How must a firm and an Authorised Person ensure their risk management arrangements are designed and maintained so they provide the practical capability to identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor risks, including in a way that can be evaluated through internal self-assessment and supervisory review?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure its risk management systems provide it with the means to identify, assess, mitigate, monitor, and control its risks, and it should be able to evidence this capability through its own internal risk self-assessment and the controls and mitigation programmes it has in place, which may be reviewed as part of an external assessment of how those risks impact supervisory objectives and the likelihood of occurrence [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1]. In parallel, an Authorised Person must establish and maintain risk management systems and controls that enable it to identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor its risks, meaning the arrangements must be operationally effective and kept current rather than being a one-off design exercise [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21]. Read together, the obligations require both the existence and ongoing maintenance of systems and controls, and that those systems demonstrably provide the tools and processes needed to manage risks across the full lifecycle from identification and assessment through mitigation, control, and monitoring, with documentation and self-assessment supporting reviewability.
source_text: Review of risk management systems. Under GEN 3.3.4, a firm must ensure that its risk management systems provide the firm with the means to identify, assess, mitigate, monitor and control its risks. In addition to undertaking our own assessment of the firm, we may review the firm's internal risk self-assessment and determine the extent to which each of the firm's risks impact our objectives, the likelihood of the risk occurring, and the controls and mitigation programmes the firm has in place.
target_text: Risk management: An Authorised Person must establish and maintain risk management systems and controls to enable it to identify, assess, mitigate, control and monitor its risks.

question: If an Authorised Person is working out PSIACOMcredit for all its Islamic Contracts, what must it do with any CR Exposure that is not more than 90 days past due, and how does that step fit with valuing the underlying asset and then choosing the risk weighting or capital charge for each contract?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person calculates PSIACOMcredit across its contracts, it must follow a defined set of steps: identify the Islamic Contracts that are in scope, value each contract’s underlying investment or asset, and reduce that value as required to produce the contract-specific value used in the calculation [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787]. If the contract involves a CR Exposure that is not past due for more than 90 days, the Authorised Person must categorise that CR Exposure into one of the required asset classes (such as cash items, exposures to central governments/central banks, banks, corporates, regulatory retail, residential mortgages, commercial real estate, or other Exposures) [#TGT:0699660d-a2de-4359-8468-2d993b6a712f]. That categorisation is the classification step that supports selecting the appropriate risk weighting or capital charge (the CRW) for the contract. After the CRW is determined, the Authorised Person applies the relevant PSIACOMcredit formula for each contract and then adds up the PSIACOMcredit results for all contracts to get the total PSIACOMcredit applicable to the Authorised Person [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787].

question: When a Relevant Person conducts business in a non-face-to-face manner and uses eKYC, what actions must it take to ensure its risk assessment identifies and mitigates the distinct money laundering risks of that delivery channel, and how must those findings be reflected in its AML/TFS policies, procedures, systems and controls?
gold_answer: Where a Relevant Person undertakes non-face-to-face (NFTF) business, including the use of eKYC, its risk assessment should explicitly identify actions to mitigate the distinct risks that can arise when business is conducted entirely NFTF versus a mix of face-to-face and NFTF interactions, and it should refer to risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant bodies [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362]. Those identified mitigation actions must then be operationalised through the Relevant Person’s obligation to establish and maintain effective policies, procedures, systems and controls to prevent opportunities for money laundering in relation to the Relevant Person and its activities [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d]. In addition, the Relevant Person must ensure that regular risk assessments are carried out on the adequacy of its AML/TFS systems and controls so they continue to enable it to identify, assess, monitor and manage money laundering risk adequately, and remain comprehensive and proportionate to the nature, scale and complexity of its activities [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d].
source_text: The risk assessment under Rule ‎6.2.1(c) should identify actions to mitigate risks associated with undertaking NFTF business generally, and the use of eKYC specifically. This is because distinct risks are often likely to arise where business is conducted entirely in an NFTF manner, compared to when the business relationship includes a mix of face-to-face and NFTF interactions. The assessment should make reference to risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, what records must be retained to satisfy both the requirement to keep a Resolution Pack (including client classification and client agreement documentation) and the general obligation to maintain sufficient records for each activity and function for at least six years?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must ensure its recordkeeping meets two linked requirements: (1) the Resolution Pack must include specified categories of records, and (2) the Authorised Person must maintain sufficient records for each activity and function for at least six years. Practically, this means the Resolution Pack should contain, at a minimum, records of Client classification and Client agreements, master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments, records and written permissions relating to the use of Client Investments, assessments and acknowledgements relating to Third-Party Agents for both Client Money and Client Investments, and the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. In parallel, the six-year recordkeeping set must include (where applicable) documents regarding Client classification and a record of each Client Agreement (including amendments), alongside broader records such as Marketing Material, records of Financial Instruments or Regulated Activities for Clients and related advice/recommendations, suitability assessment records, inducements/Soft Dollar Agreement details, financial promotions, and other Client disclosures [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2].

question: When does an investment count as a “Related Instrument” to a Financial Instrument, and if it does, what exactly is an Insider not allowed to do with that Related Instrument when they have Inside Information about the Financial Instrument?
gold_answer: A “Related Instrument” is an investment whose price or value depends on the price or value of a Financial Instrument; that dependency is what makes it “related” for insider dealing purposes [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f]. If an investment meets that definition, the insider dealing rule applies to it as well as to the underlying Financial Instrument. As a result, an Insider is prohibited from dealing or attempting to deal in relation to either the Financial Instrument to which the Inside Information relates (and, where relevant, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity to which the Inside Information relates) or the Related Instrument [#SRC:4d6d9fa5-5edd-4280-9d7b-90fca017f5d7]. For example, where an Insider has Inside Information relating to an Issuer of Financial Instruments, a Related Instrument could include a Derivative linked to those Financial Instruments, or another Financial Instrument in a member of the Issuer’s Group, so long as the price or value of that other instrument depends in whole or in part on the price or value of the Issuer’s Financial Instruments [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f].
source_text: Related Instruments. Section 92(2) prohibits an Insider from dealing or attempting to deal in relation to either the Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity (i.e. to which the Inside Information relates) or a Related Instrument.  The definition of a "Related Instrument" is set out at paragraph 1(9) of the CMC.
target_text:
Application to Financial Instruments and Related Instruments. Section 92(2) (Insider Dealing) also applies to a "Related Instrument", which is defined as meaning:
"…in relation to a Financial Instrument, an investment whose price or value depends on the price or value of the Financial Instrument."
For example, if an Insider has Inside Information relating to an Issuer, A, of Financial Instruments, then a "Related Instrument" could include a Derivative relating to the Financial Instruments of A or another Financial Instrument in a member of A's Group, if the price or value of that other Financial Instrument depends, in whole or in part, on the price or value of Financial Instruments of A.

question: When the Regulator holds Confidential Information that qualifies as CRD Information because it was received from an EEA Competent Authority under the Capital Requirements Directive, in what circumstances is the Regulator prohibited from disclosing it, and what consent and purpose limitations must be satisfied before any disclosure can occur?
gold_answer: CRD Information is a defined subset of Confidential Information: it is Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive, and an EEA Competent Authority is a public authority or body officially recognised by national law in an EEA jurisdiction and empowered to supervise institutions as part of the supervisory system [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]. Because of that origin, the Regulator is prohibited from disclosing such Confidential Information under the relevant disclosure gateways unless specific conditions are met [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c]. In particular, where the Confidential Information is CRD Information, the EEA Competent Authority that disclosed it to the Regulator must first give prior written consent to the disclosure. Further, if that consent is granted for a particular purpose, the Regulator may disclose the CRD Information only for that purpose and not for any other use or audience. These constraints operate as mandatory preconditions to any disclosure of CRD Information by the Regulator, notwithstanding other potential disclosure permissions.
source_text:
The exceptions under section 199(1) of FSMR. The provisions in section 199(2) relate specifically to Confidential Information originating in another governmental or regulatory authority, or Confidential Information that is CRD Information, and provide for and are consistent with the exchange of information and professional secrecy requirements in the European Union’s Capital Requirements Directive.  For the purposes of section 199(2):
(a)	‘CRD Information’ is defined as Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive; and
(b)	‘EEA Competent Authority’ means a public authority or body officially recognised by national law of a jurisdiction within the EEA and empowered by that national law to supervise institutions as part of the supervisory system.
target_text:
Paragraphs (1)(b)(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi) and 1(c) do not permit the Regulator to disclose Confidential Information unless the conditions in paragraphs (a) and (b) are met –
(a)	where the Confidential Information (in whole or in part) originates in another governmental or regulatory authority, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise, the authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and
(b)	where the Confidential Information is CRD Information –
(i)	EEA Competent Authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and
(ii)	if such consent was given for a particular purpose, the disclosure by the Regulator is solely for that purpose.

question: When is an Authorised Person put in Category 2, and how can you tell it is not Category 1 based on what its Financial Services Permission lets it do?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person falls into Category 2 when its Financial Services Permission allows it to do Providing Credit or to do Dealing in Investments as Principal (and not as Matched Principal), its dealing permission is not restricted to a limited scope of dealing, and it also does not meet the criteria for Categories 1 or 5 [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. The Target text adds practical classification guidance: even if the firm can do other Regulated Activities, Category 2 is driven by being authorised for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and by not being authorised for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1; it also explains that if the firm’s dealing is limited to acting only as Matched Principal, that dealing sits in Category 3A rather than Category 2 [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. You can tell it is not Category 1 because Category 1 is driven by permission to Accept Deposits or to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account that is a PSIAu (and not meeting Category 5), which is a different determinative permission set from Category 2 [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66].
source_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard, what must it say in the disclosure, given the Regulator’s expectation about complying with those non-mandatory requirements?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity should approach non-mandatory requirements in a Mining Reporting Standard as requirements it is expected to fully comply with, even though they are not described as binding, because the Regulator expects full compliance with those non-mandatory requirements (in addition to full compliance with binding requirements) [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]. When the Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard, it must address that gap directly in the disclosure itself by providing a statement that explains both (1) how the disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement and (2) why it differs [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f]. This means the disclosure should not merely note that the requirement is “non-mandatory”; it must describe the nature of the non-compliance and the reason for it, so the reader can understand the deviation against the relevant Mining Reporting Standard [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f]. This disclosure statement also aligns with the Regulator’s expectation that the Mining Reporting Entity either fully complies with non-mandatory requirements or explains its non-compliance [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124].
source_text: Rule 11.2.1(1) requires a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all binding requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard. The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.
target_text: Requirements for all disclosures. Where a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in a Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide in its disclosure a statement as to how and why its disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information based on a Production Target and also reports an Ore Reserves estimate, what must it include about (1) the assumptions behind the forecast and (2) the key technical details behind the Ore Reserves estimate?
gold_answer: For forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, a Mining Reporting Entity must include detailed disclosure about the assumptions used to determine that forecast. This includes all material economic assumptions employed, plus all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. It must also disclose the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including the required accompanying information for that Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Separately, when the Mining Reporting Entity discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, it must also include key information relating to mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status, and the relative accuracy/confidence [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129]. Together, these requirements ensure the forecast is supported by transparent assumptions and the Ore Reserves estimate is supported by key technical and confidence information [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
