question: If the Resolution Pack must include Third-Party Agent assessments and acknowledgements for Client Money and Client Investments, how does that fit with the rule that an Authorised Person must keep sufficient records for each activity and function for at least six years?
gold_answer: The Resolution Pack requirement and the six-year recordkeeping requirement work together: the Authorised Person must include certain Third-Party Agent documentation in the Resolution Pack, and it must also ensure those records are part of a broader, sufficiently complete record set retained for at least six years. The Resolution Pack must include the assessment of appropriateness of a Third-Party Agent and the acknowledgement by the Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Money, and similarly the assessment of appropriateness of a Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by the Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Separately, the Authorised Person must, for a minimum of six years, maintain sufficient records in relation to each activity and function, including (where applicable) records tied to Client-facing activities such as Financial Instruments provided to or Regulated Activities carried out for the benefit of a Client, advice or recommendations, and core client documentation like Client classification documents and Client Agreement records (including amendments) [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. So, Third-Party Agent records should be kept both as required Resolution Pack contents and within the longer-term, activity-based recordkeeping framework.

question: When is a Prospectus treated as an Approved Prospectus, and why is filing it with the Regulator not enough unless the Regulator sends the Applicant an approval notice (including for a Prospectus made up of several documents)?
gold_answer: A Prospectus is treated as an Approved Prospectus only when it has actually been approved by the Regulator in line with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and the Regulations generally treat any reference to a “Prospectus” as meaning an Approved Prospectus unless the context requires otherwise [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1]. The Source adds an important practical condition: simply filing a Prospectus with the Regulator does not make it an Approved Prospectus unless the Regulator has issued a notice to the Applicant stating that it approves the Prospectus (or, where relevant, the Supplementary Prospectus) [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. If the Prospectus is made up of multiple documents, the approval notice must state approval of all of those documents, not just some of them [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]. Put together, the Target provides the definition based on Regulator approval under the Rules, while the Source explains that the approval must be evidenced by a specific notice issued to the Applicant, and that the notice must cover the full set of documents where the Prospectus is multi-part.
source_text:
A Prospectus filed with the Regulator is not an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2)(a) of the FSMR unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval:
(a)	of the Prospectus or the Supplementary Prospectus as the case may be; and
(b)	in the case of a Prospectus in (a) comprising multiple documents, of all the multiple documents.
target_text:
For the purposes of subsection ‎(1)—
(a)	a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules; and
(b)	a reference to a Prospectus made by or under these Regulations is a reference to an Approved Prospectus, unless the context requires otherwise.

question: When a Listed Entity has already issued, or agreed to issue, Equity Securities without prior holder approval, in what circumstances is that action treated as if it had been approved, and how does that treatment interact with the prohibition on exceeding the maximum number of Equity Securities that may be issued without holder approval (including the calculation inputs that exclude or include prior issues)?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing, or agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the specified formula unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities, and the calculation depends on both the Base Amount and the subtraction of Relevant Issues [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. If an issue (or agreement to issue) was made without the required approval, it can be treated as having been made with approval for the relevant approval purposes only if three conditions are met: it did not exceed the applicable limit, the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it, and the Securities are issued within three months of that approval [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6]. This “treated as approved” status matters to the prohibition and its formula because the Target’s calculation expressly treats certain prior issues differently depending on whether they were approved (or taken under the Rules to have been approved) under the relevant approval framework: approved issues can be included in the Base Amount in specified cases and are excluded from Relevant Issues, whereas unapproved issues generally remain part of Relevant Issues and therefore reduce remaining capacity under the maximum.
source_text:
Subsequent approval of an issue of Securities. An issue of, or agreement to issue, Securities made without approval under Rule 9.7.1 is treated as having been made with approval for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1 if:
(1)	the issue or agreement did not exceed the limit in Rule 9.7.1;
(2)	the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it; and
(3)	the Securities are issued within three months of the date of the approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: When a Fund Manager appoints an auditor for a Fund, what must the Fund Manager require the auditor to do in relation to auditing the Fund’s financial statements, and what specific statements must the Fund Manager ensure the Auditor includes when producing the Fund Auditor’s Report?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager must take two linked steps that span both the audit work and the resulting reporting. First, the Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB), and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on the audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. Second, when procuring the production of that Fund Auditor’s Report, the Fund Manager must ensure that an Auditor states a defined set of matters in the report, including whether the financial statements were properly prepared in accordance with the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, whether they give a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and results for the annual accounting period, whether proper accounting records have not been kept or the statements are not in agreement with records/returns or do not comply with applicable standards, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].
source_text:
Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: When a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus would otherwise be required to pay compensation for loss arising from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission in that Prospectus, how must the compensation obligation be assessed where the person incurring the loss acquired the Securities with knowledge of the falsity, the omitted matter or change, or the new matter or inaccuracy?
gold_answer: A person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is generally liable to pay compensation to a person who acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and suffered loss or damage because of an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus, or because the Prospectus omitted a material matter required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. However, that compensation exposure must be assessed against the carve-out that a Person does not incur liability where the person incurring the loss acquired the relevant Securities with knowledge that the statement was false, misleading, or deceptive, or with knowledge of the omitted matter (or of the change), or with knowledge of the new matter or inaccuracy [#SRC:4ee654af-eec8-49f1-8813-6fb847d3eecb]. In practice, this means the compensation obligation described for Prospectus liability is not triggered against that Person in circumstances where the claimant’s acquisition was made with the specified knowledge, even if the loss is otherwise connected to the statement, omission, change, new matter, or inaccuracy.
source_text:
A Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if the Person incurring the loss acquired the Securities in question with knowledge:
(a)	that the statement was false, misleading, or deceptive;
(b)	of the omitted matter or of the change; or
(c)	of the new matter or inaccuracy.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: If a Recognised Body is failing to meet Recognition Requirements and the consequences are or will be serious, can the Regulator still use its power to direct specified remedial steps (including inspection access or suspension), and what additional factors would lead it to usually consider revocation instead?
gold_answer: The Regulator can use its power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, and those steps may include granting access to the Recognised Body’s premises for inspection of premises or documents and suspending the carrying on of any activity for a period specified in the direction [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500]. At the same time, where the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences, the Regulator will usually consider revoking the Recognition Order, indicating that revocation is a likely regulatory response in that scenario [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]. Beyond seriousness of consequences, the Regulator will usually consider revocation if it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction, or if for some other reason it would not be appropriate to give a direction. Revocation is also usually considered where the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the specified 12-month period after the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending with the day the Recognition Order is revoked [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a].
target_text: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps in order to secure its compliance with the Recognition Requirements. Those steps may include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body's premises for the purposes of inspecting those premises or any documents on the premises and the suspension of the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction.

question: When the annual report and annual financial report are prepared, what do the Board of Directors/Directors have to say about whether the Corporate Governance framework works, and what extra details must be included to back up that statement—especially if the Corporate Governance Principles or best practice standards are not fully adopted?
gold_answer: You need a Directors-level statement in the annual reporting that directly addresses whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective, and you must support that view with the right detail. In the SOURCE text, the annual report must include a statement by the Board of Directors saying whether or not, in its opinion, the Reporting Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in achieving the required governance outcome and promoting compliance with the Principles; the statement must include supporting information and assumptions, and it may include qualifications if necessary [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca]. In the TARGET text, the annual financial report of a Listed Entity must (i) state whether the Corporate Governance Principles have been adopted, (ii) if adoption is not full or is only partial, explain why and describe what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent of the shortfall, and (iii) include a statement by Directors on whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance, again with supporting information and assumptions and qualifications if necessary [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. Together, this means the effectiveness statement should be backed by the adoption status, explanations for gaps, and any actions taken.
source_text: General. The annual report required under Rule 9.2.10 must include a statement by the Board of Directors (the "Board"), stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR and promoting compliance with the Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary. As the Principles are the core of the Corporate Governance framework, the way in which they are applied should be the central question for the Board as it determines how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs under its directorship in accordance with the letter and spirit of the applicable requirements including the Principles and the standards.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: How does the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, as a component used to calculate the Capital Requirement, affect when an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator and provide written confirmation if its Capital Resources drop below the required threshold?
gold_answer: The Expenditure Based Capital Minimum matters because it is expressly identified as a component used in calculating an entity’s Capital Requirement, and that Capital Requirement is the benchmark against which the notification trigger is measured [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76]. For an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4, the obligation to notify is activated when its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement; once that condition is met, the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator immediately and then confirm the notification in writing [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]. Because the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum feeds into the calculation of the Capital Requirement, it is relevant to determining whether the 120% threshold has been breached and therefore whether the notification and written confirmation duties are triggered [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76]. In practice, the Authorised Person should ensure it is using the correct Capital Requirement calculation (including this component) when assessing its Capital Resources against the 120% test, so it can meet the immediate notification and written follow-up requirements if the threshold is crossed [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d].
source_text: The Expenditure Based Capital Minimum is a component of the calculation of the Capital Requirement under Section 3.6 and is relevant in determining whether the Regulator has to be notified under Rule 3.20.2.
target_text: Notifications to the Regulator. An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately and confirm in writing if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure about previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, what must it do to rely on the ability to omit repeating the full set of Non-Equivalent Estimate content, while still meeting the required disclosure elements for material Non-Equivalent Estimates?
gold_answer: Where a Mining Reporting Entity is disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it must ensure the disclosure contains the specified content, including a prominent and proximate statement that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not disclosed in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done sufficient work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and that it is uncertain whether they will ever be able to be disclosed as such, along with the other required supporting information (e.g., sources/dates, relevance, reliability, summaries of work and assumptions, more recent data, verification work, timing, funding, standard used, and a named Competent Person statement for certain items) [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. However, if the Mining Reporting Entity has already made an earlier disclosure that complied with those requirements, a subsequent disclosure made in respect of the same Non-Equivalent Estimates is permitted to omit the full repeated information provided it references the earlier compliant disclosure, confirms the earlier information continues to apply and that there is no new material information or data impacting reliability/interpretation or the entity’s ability to verify the estimates under a Mining Reporting Standard, and includes an at least equally prominent and proximate statement addressing the same matters as the required prominent statement [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4].
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: If a Listed Entity gets the Regulator’s approval to issue Shares with Weighted Voting Rights that change how voting power and equity interest are shared, what must the Board do to make sure investors holding the same class or type of Securities are treated equally for all rights attached to that class or type?
gold_answer: Even if a Listed Entity is allowed, with the Regulator’s approval, to allot, issue or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights that alter the equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest, the Board still has a separate duty about how investors are treated. Specifically, the Board of a Listed Entity must ensure equality of treatment of all holders of Securities of a particular class or type in respect of all rights attaching to the Securities of that class or type. That means the Board cannot rely on the fact that Weighted Voting Rights are permitted (subject to approval) to justify unequal treatment among holders within the same class or type of Securities. Instead, the Board should ensure that any approved Weighted Voting Rights are implemented in a way that preserves equal treatment for all holders within each class or type as to the rights attached to that class or type, while recognizing that the approved structure may change voting power and equity interest at the broader Shareholder level [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa] and must still satisfy the equality-of-treatment requirement [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae].
source_text: Weighted Voting Rights. A Listed Entity may, upon approval from the Regulator, allot, issue or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights, altering its Share capital in relation to the equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest (as established in Rule 9.3.3).
target_text: Equality of treatment. Subject to Rules 9.3.14 to 9.3.17, the Board of a Listed Entity must ensure equality of treatment of all holders of Securities of a particular class or type in respect of all rights attaching to the Securities of that class or type of Securities.

question: When may the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund avoid appointing a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement, given the general obligation to obtain ongoing and at least annual attestation for the relevant portion of Eligible Green Fund Property?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund generally must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but this obligation is limited in scope: it only applies to the portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] However, the Fund Manager may avoid appointing a third party where the Alternative Attestation Requirement applies. Specifically, a third-party attestation is not required if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself, which substitutes for the otherwise required third-party appointment. Alternatively, no attestation is required at all if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark. In that benchmark-tracking scenario, the exemption removes the need for any attestation notwithstanding the general ongoing and annual third-party framework. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]
source_text: The Green Fund Attestation Requirement. Subject to Rule 20.2.9, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually.  This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎20.2.3(a). This is referred to as the “Green Fund Attestation Requirement”.
target_text:
Alternative Attestation Requirement. The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund is not required to appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement if:
(a)	the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself; or
(b)	all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark pursuant to Rule ‎20.2.3(b), in which event an attestation is not required.

question: If someone is making an Offer of a Unit, do the rules in this Chapter apply to them, and does the Rulebook’s usual prospectus content and structure chapter apply to Prospectuses for Units of Funds?
gold_answer: For a person making an Offer of a Unit, the provisions in the Chapter and the Rules made for the purposes of that Chapter are stated not to apply to that person in relation to making that offer [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]. Separately, the Rulebook explains that its prospectus requirements on content and structure in chapter 4 do not apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94]. Instead of relying on those general chapter 4 prospectus requirements, the Rulebook points to a different source for what does apply: prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94]. Taken together, these two scope statements mean that Unit-related offers are carved out from the Chapter-based framework for the act of making the offer, and Fund Prospectuses are carved out from the general chapter 4 content and structure requirements, with the applicable prospectus obligations for Offers of Units of Funds being addressed through the Fund Rules rather than the general prospectus chapter [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] while the Chapter itself is disapplied for the person making the Offer of a Unit [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a].
source_text: The Prospectus requirements including content and structure in chapter 4 of this Rulebook do not apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds. Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules. Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of this Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses.
target_text: The provisions in this Chapter and the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter shall not apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit.

question: When assessing whether it must disclose information that, if made generally available, would be likely to have a significant effect on the price of Financial Instruments, how should a Mining Reporting Entity apply the definition of Inside Information (including the requirements that it be precise, not generally available, and price-sensitive) while also taking into account the FSRA’s expectation regarding commercially sensitive ore-reserve-related details?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity should start by recognising that the FSRA does not expect it to disclose commercially sensitive information (such as pricing or volumes under long-term contractual commitments) merely to satisfy the specific ore reserves disclosure obligation, but it must still consider whether the same information is required to be disclosed under other disclosure requirements, including the obligation to disclose information that would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of Financial Instruments [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856]. To make that assessment, it should test the information against the definition of Inside Information: the information must be of a precise nature, not generally available, relate directly or indirectly to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers or to the relevant Financial Instruments (or other covered instruments), and be such that, if generally available, it would be likely to have a significant effect on price [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]. If those definitional elements are met, the Mining Reporting Entity should treat the information as potentially within the scope of the price-sensitive disclosure obligation referenced by the FSRA, even if it is commercially sensitive, and document its analysis of each element (availability, precision, relationship, and price impact) in light of the disclosure triggers identified by the FSRA [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977].
source_text:
ORE RESERVES . The FSRA does expect a Mining Reporting Entity to have to disclose commercially sensitive information (e.g., pricing or volumes under long term contractual commitments) to meet this Rule obligation.  A Mining Reporting Entity (and other relevant entities) may, however, have to carefully consider whether this information needs to be disclosed to meet other disclosure requirements, including in reference to:

a)	where an Issuer is issuing a Prospectus within ADGM, and the requirement in section 62(1) of FSMR to include all information that investors would reasonably require and expect to find in a Prospectus for the purposes of making an informed investment decision; or

b)	the requirements in sections 95(2) of FSMR and Rule 7.2.1 to disclose information that ‘would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price…’ of Financial Instruments.
target_text:
In relation to Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments which are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information is information of a Precise nature which—
(a)	is not generally available;
(b)	relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and
(c)	would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments.

question: When is an Authorised Person prohibited from offering OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client or providing related advice/arrangements, and how does that prohibition interact with the requirement to reassess the relevant client assessment annually or upon a material change in the Retail Client’s financial situation or risk tolerance?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from offering OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, or from providing advice or making arrangements on behalf of a Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products, unless it has first completed an assessment of the Retail Client’s skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance and can reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has adequate experience and skill to understand the potential risk of loss and has liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0]. In addition, the assessment that underpins this gatekeeping must be kept current through reassessment by the Authorised Person on an annual basis, and also earlier where there is any material change in the Retail Client’s financial situation or risk tolerance before the annual reassessment [#SRC:98b97356-14ec-44f8-9af4-96ffa1211a76]. Read together, the prohibition means the Authorised Person should not rely on an outdated assessment when engaging in the restricted activities; instead, it must ensure the prerequisite assessment has been completed and, where required, reassessed so that the reasonable conclusions about experience, risk understanding, and liquid resources remain valid at the time of offering, advising, or arranging.
source_text:
The assessment required by Rule 23.5.1 must be reassessed by an Authorised Person:
(a)	on an annual basis; or
(b)	where there is any material change in the financial situation or risk tolerance of the Retail Client, if that change occurs prior to the annual reassessment.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must not offer OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, or provide any advice or make arrangements on behalf of a Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products unless it has first completed an assessment of the skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance of the Retail Client, such that the Authorised Person may reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has:
(a)	adequate experience and skill enabling them to understand the potential risk of loss involved in investing in OTC Leveraged Products; and
(b)	liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses resulting from trading in OTC Leveraged Products.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, what must be done to ensure reconciliations of Client Accounts are performed with the required frequency and accuracy, and what reconciliation evidence must be retained within the Resolution Pack regarding Client Money and Client Investments?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must operate adequate systems and controls that ensure reconciliations of Client Accounts are accurate and performed as often as necessary, with a minimum frequency of at least every calendar month [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b]. In addition to meeting that operational requirement, the Authorised Person must also ensure that the Resolution Pack includes the most recent reconciliations relating specifically to Client Money and Client Investments, so that there is readily available documentary evidence of the latest reconciliation activity for those client asset categories [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Taken together, these obligations mean the firm should both (i) run a reconciliation process on a schedule that cannot fall below monthly and that is designed to produce accurate outcomes, and (ii) retain and file the latest completed reconciliation outputs for Client Money and Client Investments in the Resolution Pack, so the most current reconciliation records are captured and accessible.
target_text: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must maintain adequate systems and controls to ensure that accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts are carried out as regularly as necessary but at least every calendar month.

question: If the Regulator has Confidential Information that counts as CRD Information because it came from an EEA Competent Authority under the Capital Requirements Directive, what is the Regulator not allowed to do, unless it gets the right written consent?
gold_answer: CRD Information is a specific kind of Confidential Information: it is Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive, and the EEA Competent Authority is an officially recognised EEA public authority or body empowered by national law to supervise institutions [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]. Because the information is CRD Information, the Regulator is not allowed to disclose it through the relevant disclosure routes unless the required conditions are met [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c]. The key condition is prior written consent from the EEA Competent Authority that provided the Confidential Information to the Regulator. Also, if that consent is given only for a particular purpose, the Regulator must limit any disclosure to that purpose only. In practice, this means the Regulator must check both (1) whether the Confidential Information meets the CRD Information definition and (2) whether the EEA Competent Authority has provided written consent, including any stated purpose limits, before disclosing anything.
source_text:
The exceptions under section 199(1) of FSMR. The provisions in section 199(2) relate specifically to Confidential Information originating in another governmental or regulatory authority, or Confidential Information that is CRD Information, and provide for and are consistent with the exchange of information and professional secrecy requirements in the European Union’s Capital Requirements Directive.  For the purposes of section 199(2):
(a)	‘CRD Information’ is defined as Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive; and
(b)	‘EEA Competent Authority’ means a public authority or body officially recognised by national law of a jurisdiction within the EEA and empowered by that national law to supervise institutions as part of the supervisory system.
target_text:
Paragraphs (1)(b)(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi) and 1(c) do not permit the Regulator to disclose Confidential Information unless the conditions in paragraphs (a) and (b) are met –
(a)	where the Confidential Information (in whole or in part) originates in another governmental or regulatory authority, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise, the authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and
(b)	where the Confidential Information is CRD Information –
(i)	EEA Competent Authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and
(ii)	if such consent was given for a particular purpose, the disclosure by the Regulator is solely for that purpose.

question: Where the Resolution Pack must include master lists of Client Accounts and the most recent reconciliations for Client Money and Client Investments, how must an Authorised Person align those inclusions with the requirement to maintain sufficient records for each activity and function for a minimum six-year period?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must treat the Resolution Pack inclusions as part of its wider obligation to maintain sufficient records for each activity and function for at least six years. Specifically, where the Resolution Pack must include master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments, and the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, those items should be maintained in a manner that supports ongoing record sufficiency and retention over the minimum six-year period [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. This alignment requires the Authorised Person to ensure that, in addition to keeping these Resolution Pack components current and available, its overall records framework also captures the broader “sufficient records” set (where applicable), including records of Financial Instruments provided to or Regulated Activities carried out for the benefit of a Client, advice or recommendations made to a Client, and other required documentation such as Client classification documents and Client Agreement records (including amendments) [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. In effect, the Resolution Pack is a defined subset of records that must be included, while the six-year obligation governs retention and completeness across all activities and functions.

question: When is a Recognised Investment Exchange not allowed to let Securities trade on its facilities, and how can the Regulator change chapter requirements to help an Exempt Offeror get its Securities onto the Official List so trading can be sought?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless the Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List, except where otherwise prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator [#TGT:76d81d0b-f659-47be-bcb8-a99a24187cac]. The Source explains why this matters for an Exempt Offeror: if the Exempt Offeror wants to voluntarily comply with the Listing Rules so it can include its Securities on the Official List and thereby seek admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, the Regulator may also modify one or more requirements of the chapter to support that outcome [#SRC:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc]. It also states that, without such a modification, an Exempt Offeror cannot have its Securities included in the Official List [#SRC:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc]. Putting the two together, the trading restriction means Official List admission (and not being suspended) is the default gateway to trading, and the Regulator’s ability to modify chapter requirements is the lever described for enabling an Exempt Offeror—who is voluntarily following the Listing Rules—to achieve Official List inclusion so that the Recognised Investment Exchange can lawfully permit trading, subject to any prescribed exception [#TGT:76d81d0b-f659-47be-bcb8-a99a24187cac].
source_text: The Regulator may also modify one or more requirements of this chapter for an Exempt Offeror who wishes to voluntarily comply with the Listing Rules in order to include its Securities on the Official List and thereby seek admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. Without such a modification an Exempt Offeror cannot have its Securities included in the Official List. This is because section 50(3) of the FSMR requires that a Recognised Investment Exchange shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List.
target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List except where otherwise prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator.

question: If an Authorised Person is a Branch, what must it keep in place so there is no significant risk it cannot pay liabilities when they are due, and how can it use the listed liquidity options (cash or marketable assets, matching cashflows, or borrowing) to meet that requirement?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is a Branch must ensure it has and maintains, at all times, liquid assets and access to financial resources that are adequate for its business in both amount and quality, so that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due [#TGT:9fbb61f7-59fe-4340-85f8-ab6b9e7fb03c]. The general obligation on an Authorised Person is aligned to the same outcome—avoiding a significant risk of being unable to meet liabilities as they fall due—and it explains practical liquidity ways an Authorised Person may meet its obligations [#SRC:456ed7d2-778d-4597-862e-2c4582c20c87]. In practice for a Branch, this means the Branch should structure its liquid assets and broader financial resources using one or more of the described options: keeping sufficient immediately available cash or readily marketable assets, arranging an appropriate future cashflow profile that matches expected outflows, and, where appropriate, maintaining the ability to borrow further [#SRC:456ed7d2-778d-4597-862e-2c4582c20c87]. The key is that these measures must remain adequate at all times for the Branch’s business profile and must collectively support the stated “no significant risk” standard [#TGT:9fbb61f7-59fe-4340-85f8-ab6b9e7fb03c].
source_text:
In accordance with Rule 3.2.2 or Rule 3.2.4, an Authorised Person is required to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. With specific reference to liquidity, an Authorised Person may meet its obligations in a number of ways, including:
a.	by holding sufficient immediately available cash or readily marketable assets;
b.	by securing an appropriate matching future profile of cashflows; and
c.	by further borrowing.

question: If the Regulator decides it can refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (fully or partly) because one of the listed conditions applies, can it still use Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers to support that foreign action, and what approval limits apply?
gold_answer: The Regulator can only use Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers to support, or give full effect to, a foreign action where that action is a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action. Under the SOURCE, the Regulator may refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action in whole or in part if it is satisfied that one or more specified conditions are met, such as an adverse effect on financial stability in the ADGM, the Resolution Conditions not being met for the relevant entity, Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch not being necessary to achieve Resolution Objectives, unequal treatment or legal rights for creditors located or payable in the ADGM compared with creditors in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction, or material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]. The TARGET then states that, for supporting or giving full effect to a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may exercise one or more Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers, but this is subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval [#TGT:5798f720-7021-4b63-9ebe-f1a30aebee29]. So if recognition is refused (or refused in part), the Regulator’s ability to take supporting action is correspondingly reduced, and any permitted action must still comply with any ex-ante judicial approval requirement.
target_text: For the purposes of supporting, or giving full effect to, a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may exercise one or more Resolution Tools, or one or more Resolution Powers, subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval in compliance with section 27.

question: When the Investigator asks for documents from the Person Under Investigation or another person, does the Investigator have the option to require either copies or originals, and can the Investigator keep any originals while they are needed, even if the person has to get the documents from someone else?
gold_answer: Yes. The Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to produce specified documents or documents of a specified description at a specified time and place [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. The Investigator’s authority also covers requiring a person to produce documents or to procure the production of documents, which addresses cases where the person must arrange for documents to be produced rather than simply handing over what they already have [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]. The Investigator can require production of original documents or copies, so the request can specify the form in which the documents must be provided [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]. If originals are produced, the Investigator may retain possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested, meaning retention is allowed for the period needed to meet that purpose [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3].
source_text: Power to require documents or information . Section 206(1)(b) of FSMR empowers the Investigator to require a person to produce, or procure the production of, specified documents or documents of a specified description. It empowers the Investigator to require production of original documents or copies. The Investigator may retain possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, what must it do to ensure the disclosure is both properly attributed to named Competent Person(s) and is issued only with the necessary prior written consent regarding how the information is presented?
gold_answer: For a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that contains Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, the disclosure must include specific Competent Person attribution statements and also be controlled by the Competent Person(s) through prior written consent on presentation. First, the disclosure must state that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). It must also state, for each Competent Person, whether the person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party; if not, it must identify the Competent Person’s employer. In addition, it must state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]. Separately, where the disclosure involves Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves and supporting information, it must only be made with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which that information is presented [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8].
source_text: Competent Persons . The disclosure made in Rule 11.12.1 must only be made with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: What must be included in the first Production Target disclosure, and what extra steps let a Mining Reporting Entity avoid repeating that same information in a later Production Target disclosure?
gold_answer: For the first disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2, the Mining Reporting Entity must include required information about the assumptions used to determine the Production Target, including all material economic assumptions (or, if it considers them commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine them) and all other material assumptions utilised; it must also include other required Production Target items such as any statement that forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, the proportions of the Production Target based on different categories (including Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target), and the required statements addressing viability and the required cautionary statements where applicable [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. After that, a later disclosure in relation to the Production Target is allowed to leave out the information that would otherwise have to be disclosed again, but only if the Mining Reporting Entity references the earlier disclosure that was compliant with those information requirements and includes a confirmation that all the material assumptions in the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. If the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement to the relevant effect [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: Can the Investigator make someone give information during an investigation, and does this apply only to the Person Under Investigation or also to other people? What does “information” cover?
gold_answer: Yes. The Investigator may use a written notice to require the person who is the Person Under Investigation, or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation), to provide such information as the Investigator may require [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. This matches the Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. The term “information” is meant to be read broadly in its ordinary sense, so it is not limited to formal records. It can include knowledge communicated or received about a matter, fact, or circumstance, and knowledge gained through work, commerce, study, communication, research, or instruction [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. It can also include computer-related data at any stage of processing, including input, output, storage, or transmission data. In addition, “information” can be an explanation or statement about a matter, the identification of a person/matter/thing, or simply a response to a question—consistent with the Investigator’s ability to require a person to answer questions (for example, at an interview) [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32].

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information and that forecast is based on a Production Target, what information must it include about the assumptions and the Production Target, especially if the economic assumptions are commercially sensitive or if the Production Target uses Inferred Mineral Resources or an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s forecast financial information is derived from a Production Target, its disclosure must include the Production Target that the forecast is derived from, and it must also include the required information that accompanies a Production Target disclosure [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. On assumptions, it must disclose all material economic assumptions and all other material assumptions used; if it considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine those assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] and [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. For the Production Target itself, it must state whether forecast commodity prices were used and, if they were, confirm those forecast prices were arrived at on reasonable grounds. It must also break down the proportions of the Production Target based on Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources (including Inferred Mineral Resources), and any Exploration Target, and include the required prominent cautionary statements and related explanations where the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly based on an Exploration Target, including the additional support requirements when it is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: During a period of financial or liquidity stress, if an Authorised Person liquidates part of its stock of HQLA to generate cash for outflows and, as a result, its HQLA level falls below what is required for its LCR Requirement, what notification must it make to the Regulator and when must that notification be made?
gold_answer: During a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person is permitted to liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows, and its level of HQLA may fall below the levels required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with those outflows [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f]. However, if the Authorised Person does not meet its LCR Requirement as a consequence of that liquidation and resulting reduction in HQLA, or if it becomes aware of circumstances arising from the stress and outflows that may result in it not meeting its LCR Requirement, it must notify the Regulator in writing immediately [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c]. This obligation applies at any time, and expressly includes periods of stress, so the permissibility of drawing down HQLA to manage outflows does not remove the requirement to provide immediate written notice when the LCR Requirement is not met or is at risk of not being met [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f] [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c].
source_text: Liquidation of assets during periods of stress . During a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person may liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows. Subject to Rule 9.3.9, the Authorised Person's level of HQLA may fall below the levels required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with cash outflows during that period.
target_text: Notification if LCR Requirement is not met . An Authorised Person must notify the Regulator in writing immediately if it does not meet, or becomes aware of circumstances that may result in it not meeting, at any time, its LCR Requirement (including during a period of stress referred to in Rule 9.3.8).

question: If a person is listed in the Regulator’s Rules as liable for a Prospectus and must pay compensation when an investor loses money because the Prospectus had a misleading statement or left out an important required matter, what can that person show or do so they do not incur civil liability—especially if they fixed the issue before anyone bought the Securities relying on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: A person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to someone who acquired the Securities covered by that Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. Even so, that person does not incur civil liability if they can demonstrate one of the permitted defenses: (a) the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive, or the omitted matter that caused the loss was properly omitted; (b) they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or (c) before the Securities were acquired by any person in reliance on the Prospectus, they took all steps that were reasonable for them to take to ensure a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of persons likely to acquire the Securities [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554].
source_text:
A Person does not incur civil liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if that Person can show that:
(a)	the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive or that the matter the omission of which caused the loss was properly omitted;
(b)	he made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed that there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or
(c)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person in reliance on the Prospectus, he had taken all such steps as were reasonable for him to have taken to secure that a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of the Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: When can the Regulator allow a holding lock to be released so Restricted Securities holders can take part in a Takeover (accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities), and what must be true before the Regulator will give that consent?
gold_answer: The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock so holders of Restricted Securities can accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover [#TGT:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67]. But the Regulator will not provide its consent unless the relevant requirements are met, to the extent they apply [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]. If there is an offer for Securities, the offer must be for all of the Ordinary Securities, or (if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities) for all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities. Also, holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities covered by the offer must have accepted. If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock will be immediately re-imposed for each Security the offeror does not buy. If the offer is done as a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity where the Restricted Securities are held must agree in writing that the holding lock will be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
source_text:
Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator will not provide its consent under Rule 9.6.11 unless, to the extent to which they are applicable, all the following requirements are met:
(1)	where there is an offer for Securities:
(a)	the offer is for all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all the Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities;
(b)	holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities, to which the offer relates, have accepted; and
(c)	if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder agree in writing that the holding lock (imposed under Rule 9.6.9) be immediately re-imposed for each Security that is not bought by the offeror under the offer; and
(2)	where the offer is to be conducted by way of a ‘scheme’, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
target_text: Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.

question: If the Investigator sends a written notice telling the Person Under Investigation (or someone else) to bring certain documents at a set time and place, can the Investigator also make that person arrange for the documents to be produced, and can the Investigator ask for originals and keep them as long as needed?
gold_answer: Yes. The Investigator may use a written notice to require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to produce specified documents or documents of a specified description at a specified time and place [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Alongside that, the Investigator is empowered to require a person to produce documents or to procure the production of documents, meaning the person can be required not only to hand over documents they hold but also to take steps to ensure the documents are produced where they are held elsewhere [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]. The Investigator can also require that the documents be produced as originals or as copies, depending on what is requested [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]. If originals are produced, the Investigator may retain possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested, so the originals can be kept while they are needed for that purpose [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3].
source_text: Power to require documents or information . Section 206(1)(b) of FSMR empowers the Investigator to require a person to produce, or procure the production of, specified documents or documents of a specified description. It empowers the Investigator to require production of original documents or copies. The Investigator may retain possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested.

question: When an executed Third Party Transaction is later confirmed to have been unauthorised or incorrectly executed and it results in an unauthorised Payment Transaction, what refunds must the Third Party Provider make, to whom, and by what deadline, taking into account any prerequisite conditions and offsets between the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer?
gold_answer: Where the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide a refund as soon as practicable and, in any event, no later than the end of the day following the day of that confirmation [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. In the specific scenario where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with the applicable authorisation requirement and the Third Party Transaction leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider’s refund obligations are twofold and are expressly subject to the stated conditions: it must refund the Primary Financial Institution for the amount the Primary Financial Institution may have already refunded to the Customer, and it must also refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, reduced by any amount it has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe]. Read together, the timing requirement governs how quickly the Third Party Provider must effect the required refunds, while the allocation and netting mechanics determine the correct payees and prevent double recovery when the Primary Financial Institution has already compensated the Customer.
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.
target_text:
Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. Subject to Rules 20.10 and 20.11, where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and the Third Party Transaction leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must:
(a)	refund the Primary Financial Institution for the amount that the Primary Financial Institution may have already refunded to the Customer; and
(b)	refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, less any amount that the Third Party Provider has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution.

question: If an ADGM Green Portfolio holds Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, does the Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager still have to hire a third party to attest compliance at least every year, and which part of the assets does that attestation cover?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but the obligation is expressly limited to the portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. At the same time, the scope statement provides that the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]. Putting these together, the Investment Manager’s third-party attestation should not be required for the benchmark-tracking Eligible Green Portfolio Assets, even though the Investment Manager still has an attestation obligation for any remaining portion of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy. The practical result is that the attestation engagement should be structured to cover only the in-scope portion and to exclude the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark-tracking portion.
source_text: Under Rule 3.8.6, the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets which are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(b).
target_text: The Green Porftolio Attestation Requirement. The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually. This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(a). This requirement is referred to as the “Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement”.

question: If an Authorised Person is going to let a Third Party Agent hold Safe Custody Assets, what must the Third Party Agent confirm in writing, and does that written confirmation need to be kept in the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack for Client Investments records?
gold_answer: Before an Authorised Person passes, or permits to be passed, Safe Custody Assets to a Third Party Agent, it must first obtain a written acknowledgement from the Third Party Agent that sets out key protections for Client Investments. This includes confirming the account name clearly separates Client holdings from any Investments belonging to the Authorised Person; that Client Investment movements happen only on the Authorised Person’s instructions; that Client Investments are held separately from the Third Party Agent’s own assets; and that there are defined arrangements for recordkeeping/registration, handling dividends and other entitlements, and giving/receiving instructions. The acknowledgement must also cover that the Third Party Agent will provide statements (with an agreed frequency) detailing Client Investments in the account, that the account cannot be combined with other accounts and is not subject to charges, liens, set-off, or counterclaims for sums owed on other accounts, and the Third Party Agent’s liability if it defaults [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98]. Separately, the Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include specified records, including those relating to Third Party Agent acknowledgements for Client Investments, so this written acknowledgement must be kept as part of the Resolution Pack records [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5].

question: If an Authorised Person needs to work out RWA for both securitisation Exposures and Early Amortisation Exposures, what steps do they follow for each, and what do they add together at the end?
