It also includes explanations or statements, identification details, and responses to questions—meaning that oral or written answers, clarifications, and identifications can fall within “information” even where no specific document is being produced [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].

question: If a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, how does it have to send the refusal notice, and where should the agreed way of sending notices be written down for the Customer?
gold_answer: When a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction, it must send a notification of that refusal, and it must send it using the agreed manner for providing the notification [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575]. The place where that “agreed manner” should be clearly set out for the Customer is the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers, unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer otherwise agree in writing [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. The Governing Contract must include the means of communication agreed between the parties for transmitting information or notifications, and it must also cover any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software to receive those notifications [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. This ensures the Customer knows exactly how refusal notifications will be delivered (for example, via the agreed communication channel) and what is needed to receive them, so the Third Party Provider can meet its obligation to notify in the agreed manner when a refusal occurs [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49].
source_text: Refusal of Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide the notification in the agreed manner of the refusal as set out in Rule 20.2.2.

question: If an MTF Operator or OTF Operator must follow certain MIR rulebook requirements by reading references to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange as references to itself, what does it have to treat “Investment(s)” and “Financial Instrument(s)” as meaning when COBS Chapter 8 is being applied for the stated purposes?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person acting as an MTF Operator or an OTF Operator is required to comply with the listed MIR rulebook requirements that apply to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange, but it must apply them by treating references to those entities in the relevant rules as references to the MTF Operator or OTF Operator [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094]. In parallel, for the stated purposes affecting how COBS Chapter 8 is read, the firm must translate key product terms in a specific way: “Investment” and “Investments” must be read as “Spot Commodity” and “Spot Commodities,” and “Financial Instrument” and “Financial Instruments” must be read as “Accepted Spot Commodity” and “Accepted Spot Commodities,” including where those “Financial Instrument(s)” references appear in MIR material that is incorporated through COBS Rule 8.2.1 [#SRC:27f8e3fb-1055-4605-bb11-0b75eba743c2]. So, when the firm is implementing the MIR obligations it must follow, and the relevant COBS Chapter 8 context is engaged for those purposes, it should treat the obligations as applying to spot commodities and accepted spot commodities rather than to investments or financial instruments.
source_text:
For the purposes of Rules 22.7.1 and 22.7.2, the following references in COBS, Chapter 8 should be read as follows:
(a)	references to “Investment” or “Investments” shall be read as references to “Spot Commodity” or “Spot Commodities”, and
(b)	references to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including those in MIR as incorporated by virtue of COBS Rule 8.2.1) shall be read as references to “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities” as applicable.

question: Can the Regulator choose to publish a decision notice or final notice (and details about the case), and what happens if a person takes the decision to the Appeals Panel?
gold_answer: Yes. The Regulator is permitted to publish a decision notice, final notice, or another notice linked to the exercise of the Regulator’s powers, along with details about the matter the notice relates to, as long as it is not a warning notice. This is described as a discretionary power: publication may occur at the Regulator’s discretion, rather than being automatic in every case. The SOURCE then explains how that discretion is expected to be applied in a particular situation: if a person uses their right to refer a decision to the Appeals Panel, the Regulator will publish appropriate information about that decision, and this publication will include the notice itself. Taken together, the TARGET provides the general permission and scope of what may be published (types of notices and related details), while the SOURCE adds the practical outcome for Appeals Panel referrals, indicating that publication will follow in that scenario and will cover both the notice and suitable information about the decision. [#SRC:9ddabd85-89c9-44a4-a291-0388531f1314] [#TGT:de87bb07-107e-4bc3-a834-8f7457702841]
source_text: Under section 252(3) of FSMR, we have the discretion to publish a decision notice, final notice or any other notice in relation to the exercise of our powers (other than a warning notice), and details about the matter to which the notice relates. Therefore, if a person exercises their right to refer a decision to the Appeals Panel, we will publish appropriate information about that decision, including the notice itself.
target_text: A decision notice, final notice or any other notice in relation to the exercise of the Regulator's powers (other than a warning notice), and details about the matter to which such notice relates, may be published by the Regulator at its discretion.

question: When a Fund Manager proposes to remove and replace the Trustee of an Investment Trust, what independence condition must the replacement Trustee satisfy in relation to the Fund Manager, and what submissions must be provided so the Regulator may grant approval for the replacement?
gold_answer: In seeking to replace a Trustee, the Fund Manager must ensure the proposed replacement Trustee satisfies the independence requirement applicable to a Trustee of an Investment Trust, meaning the Trustee must be independent of the Fund Manager and must not fall within any of the specified non-independence relationships (including cross-shareholdings or voting rights, common holding company arrangements, overlapping Directors on the Governing Body, shared individuals performing Controlled Functions, or professional/material business dealings within the previous two years other than acting in their respective roles) [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]. The Regulator is permitted to grant approval for the replacement only after it has received a written notice from the Fund Manager stating its intention to remove the Trustee, together with either a certification that the removal will not adversely affect Unitholders’ interests and the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with its obligations, or a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. In addition, the Regulator must receive the written consent of the person agreeing to act as the replacement Trustee, and that person must meet the applicable requirements to be able to act as the replacement Trustee [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2].
source_text:
The Regulator may grant approval for the replacement of a Trustee only where it has received:
(a)	a written notice from the Fund Manager of its intention to remove the Trustee and either:
(i)	a certification that the removal of the Trustee will not adversely affect the interests of the Unitholders and the Fund Manager's ability to comply with its obligations under the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR; or
(ii)	a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the Fund Manager's proposal to remove the Trustee and its replacement with another Trustee; and
(b)	the written consent of the person who agrees to be the replacement Trustee, and that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act as the replacement Trustee.

question: If an MTF Operator lists Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF so they can be traded by Professional Clients and up to 200 assessed Retail Clients, what systems and controls must the MTF have to admit the Securities and limit who can trade them?
gold_answer: The source allows an MTF Operator to list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF (whether or not they were previously offered through a PFP) and describes the intended trading limits: trading may occur among an unlimited number of Professional Clients, but only up to 200 Retail Clients, and only where those Retail Clients have been assessed by the MTF Operator as having appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f]. If the MTF admits these Securities to trading, the target requires the MTF to back that listing decision with effective systems and controls. Specifically, the MTF must ensure it admits only Securities of Exempt Offers that are made on its own platform, and it must be able to identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. It must also restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade, which supports the source’s cap on non-professional participation [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. In addition, the MTF must have controls to meet applicable admission-to-trading requirements and to allow users to obtain Inside Information, including relevant offer documents, so that trading happens with appropriate information access [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66].
source_text: In respect of Securities offered by Exempt Offer, whether previously offered through a PFP or not, an MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, enabling such Securities to be traded amongst an unlimited number of Professional Clients and not more than 200 Retail Clients which have been assessed by the MTF Operator to possess appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks, in accordance with Market Infrastructure Rules (MIR) Rule 2.8.3. A description of the systems and controls required to be employed by a MTF Operator that seeks to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading is set out in Conduct of Business Rules (COBS) Rule 8.2.2.

question: Can a person ask the Appeals Panel to fully review a Regulator decision that affects them, and does the wider description also say that some non‑Part 21 decisions may still be referred even though operational decisions cannot?
gold_answer: A person can refer a decision to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review when the decision is made under these Regulations by the Regulator (or when the matter concerns Rules made by the Regulator) and it may affect the person’s rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect the person’s interests [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23]. The wider description of the referral framework adds two important clarifications. First, it indicates that operational decisions are excluded from the set of decisions that may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. Second, it explains that certain other decisions may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review even if they are not subject to the Part 21 procedure, and it provides the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers as an example [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. In practice, this means the person’s ability to refer depends on the decision’s adverse impact, with an operational-decision carve-out and an additional category of referable non‑Part 21 decisions.
source_text: Section 225(1) of FSMR provides that all of our decisions that may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person (except operational decisions) may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review. FSMR also specifies that certain other decisions, not subject to the Part 21 procedure, may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review (e.g., exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers).
target_text: Any decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator or Rules made by the Regulator which may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person, may be referred by that person to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review .

question: In meeting its obligations around the Fund Auditor’s Report, how must a Fund Manager structure its written instruction to the auditor regarding the audit, and what minimum content must the Fund Manager ensure the Auditor expressly addresses in the report for the annual accounting period?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager’s obligations operate as a chain from instruction to deliverable. The Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in accordance with the relevant IAASB standards and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on those audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. Beyond requiring the report, the Fund Manager must also manage the report’s substance: in procuring the production of the Fund Auditor’s Report, the Fund Manager must ensure that an Auditor states at least the specified conclusions and disclosures. These include whether the financial statements were properly prepared under the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, whether they present a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and performance for the annual accounting period and at period end, and whether there are issues such as accounting records not being kept, lack of agreement between statements and records/returns, or non-compliance with applicable financial reporting standards [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]. The Auditor must also state whether it received all information and explanations necessary for the audit, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter or opinion required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].
source_text:
Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: When a Recognised Clearing House works out how much capital it must hold for the different risks, what is the required source for the latest audited expense information, and how must those operational expenses be handled for accounting?
gold_answer: A Recognised Clearing House must base the operational-expense numbers used in its capital calculations on the most recent audited information from its annual financial statement, and it must consider those operational expenses in line with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0]. This is important because the Recognised Clearing House is required to hold capital that is at least equal to the sum of the capital calculated for the specified risks, and some of those required risk components are explicitly tied to gross operational expenses and annual gross operational expenses [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b]. For example, the winding down or restructuring activities component is set by reference to six months’ gross operational expenses, and the business-risk component has a minimum amount expressed as a percentage of annual gross operational expenses (even though the Recognised Clearing House must submit its own estimate for approval) [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b]. Using the most recent audited annual financial statement data and applying IFRS treatment ensures those expense-based inputs are derived and handled on the required basis when building up the overall capital sum [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0].
source_text: For the purposes of Rule ‎4.2.1, Recognised Clearing Houses shall use the most recent audited information from their annual financial statement and operational expenses shall be considered in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).
target_text:
A Recognised Clearing House shall hold capital more than or equal to the sum of capital calculated in respect of the following risks.
(a)	Winding down or restructuring activities. Six months' gross operational expenses.
(b)	Operational risks. A Recognised Clearing House shall calculate its capital requirement for operational risks using either the Basic Indicator Approach or, with prior authorisation from the Regulator, the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, both as provided specifically in Appendix 7.3 and generally in Appendix 7 of PRU.
(c)	Credit, counterparty credit and market risks. A Recognised Clearing House shall calculate its capital requirements as the sum of 10% of its risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit and counterparty credit risk and its capital requirements for market risk calculated in accordance with Appendix 6 of PRU, subject to the following.
(i)	For the calculation of the risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit risk and counterparty credit risk, a Recognised Clearing House shall apply the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) method in section 4.8 of PRU.
(ii)	Where a Recognised Clearing House does not use its own resources, the Recognised Clearing House shall apply a risk weight of 250% to its exposure stemming from any contributions to the default fund of another Clearing house and a risk weight of 2% to any trade exposures with another Clearing house.
(d)	Business risk. A Recognised Clearing House shall submit to the Regulator for approval its own estimate of the capital necessary to cover losses resulting from business risk based on reasonably foreseeable adverse scenarios relevant to its business model. The capital requirement for business risk shall be equal to the approved estimate and shall be subject to a minimum amount of 25% of its annual gross operational expenses.

question: When an Authorised Person is required to submit returns to the Regulator using EPRS, how must it proceed if the Regulator issues a written notice directing submission in a different form, manner, or frequency than otherwise prescribed, and for how long must that direction be followed?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person’s baseline obligation is to prepare its returns in accordance with the Rules in the relevant Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the requirements of the Regulator’s Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS), including the frequency of submission specified through those EPRS requirements, and then to submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS [#SRC:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9]. However, this EPRS-based submission obligation operates subject to the Regulator’s power to vary how returns are submitted: the Regulator may, by written notice, direct an Authorised Person to submit its returns in a form, manner, or frequency other than the otherwise prescribed approach [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]. Where such a written direction is issued, the Authorised Person must continue submitting its returns in accordance with that direction, and it must keep doing so until the Regulator issues a further written notice directing otherwise [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b].
source_text:
An Authorised Person must, subject to Rule 2.3.3:
(a)	prepare its returns in accordance with the Rules in this Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the requirements of the Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS) of the Regulator including the frequency of submission detailed therein; and
(b)	submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS.
target_text: The Regulator may by way of a written notice direct an Authorised Person to submit its returns in a form, manner or frequency other than as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2.  An Authorised Person must continue to submit its returns in accordance with this direction until the Regulator by way of written notice directs otherwise.

question: Before a PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal relating to a PFP Prospect, what due diligence must it perform on the PFP Prospect, and what platform disclosures must it ensure are made available to PFP Clients regarding both the risks of participating and the methodology and limitations of that due diligence?
gold_answer: Before publishing any financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect to support its disclosure obligations, and that due diligence must include (at a minimum) reviewing management details and background (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers), the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status where relevant), and the financing proposal itself to ensure, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, that the content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. In parallel, the PFP Operator must ensure that information available to PFP Clients is published on the Private Financing Platform it operates, including a statement identifying the risks involved in participating in financing proposals on the platform, details of any financing proposal published, the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication, and the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence undertaken by the PFP Operator concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the platform [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]. Together, these requirements link the pre-publication review of the PFP Prospect and proposal with transparent client-facing disclosure about risks and how the PFP Operator’s due diligence is conducted and bounded.
source_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is using the FCCA, and the transaction is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, what must the Authorised Person do to determine the adjusted exposure value and how must that value be used in the credit risk exposure calculation, taking into account the required haircut-based methodology and the exclusion of OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and is using the FCCA, it must calculate an adjusted exposure value (E*) in accordance with the applicable Rules and then use that E* in place of the unadjusted exposure (E) when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the relevant CR Exposure [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de]. For collateralised transactions within scope of the haircut approach—i.e., transactions not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement or a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, and excluding OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions—the Authorised Person must compute E* using the specified formula that applies supervisory or own-estimate haircuts under the FCCA [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949]. This requires determining E as the fair value of the Exposure, applying the appropriate Exposure haircut (HE), valuing the eligible financial Collateral received (C), applying the appropriate Collateral haircut (HC, including weighted treatment for baskets), and applying any currency mismatch haircut (HFX), with E* floored at zero. The resulting E* is the exposure value after risk mitigation and is the value substituted into the credit risk exposure calculation.
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.

question: Before a PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, what due diligence must it perform to support its disclosure obligations, and for how long must it maintain records evidencing that due diligence and related communications and disclosures?
gold_answer: Before publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence on the PFP Prospect to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it, and that due diligence must include (at a minimum) reviewing information provided by the PFP Prospect covering: (i) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (ii) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing and (where relevant) regulatory status; and (iii) the financing proposal itself to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. In addition, the PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep records of the due diligence it undertook, as well as all disclosures made in accordance with the applicable disclosure rules and all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.
target_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: When the Investigator issues a written notice requiring a Person Under Investigation or another person to produce specified documents at a specified time and place, can the Investigator also require that person to procure the production of those documents (including originals or copies), and may the Investigator retain any original documents for as long as necessary for the purpose for which they were requested?
gold_answer: Yes. The Investigator’s written-notice power to require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to produce specified documents or documents of a specified description at a specified time and place supports compelling document production through that notice mechanism [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. In addition, the Investigator is empowered to require a person not only to produce documents but also to procure the production of specified documents or documents of a specified description, which addresses situations where the recipient must arrange for documents to be produced by another holder or source [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]. The same empowerment extends to requiring production of original documents or copies, allowing the Investigator to specify the form of production depending on investigative needs [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]. Where originals are produced, the Investigator may retain possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested, aligning retention with the investigative purpose rather than a fixed period [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3].
source_text: Power to require documents or information . Section 206(1)(b) of FSMR empowers the Investigator to require a person to produce, or procure the production of, specified documents or documents of a specified description. It empowers the Investigator to require production of original documents or copies. The Investigator may retain possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target and also discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, what specific categories of assumptions and other key supporting information must be included to satisfy both disclosure obligations?
gold_answer: Where a Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, it must include comprehensive information about the assumptions used to determine that forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions employed, any statement that such material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive (if the Mining Reporting Entity considers them so) together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine them, and all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In addition, the disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required to accompany that Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Separately, when the Mining Reporting Entity discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure must also include key information relating to mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status, and the relative accuracy/confidence [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129]. Read together, the combined disclosure package must cover both the forecast-related assumption set (economic and other material assumptions plus the Production Target basis) and the Ore Reserves-specific technical and confidence information [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Rule 11.6 also requires that when a Mining Reporting Entity discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure is also to include key information relating to mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status and the relative accuracy/confidence.

question: If someone wants Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, do they have to avoid doing so unless there is an Approved Prospectus, or does that “shall not” rule not apply when the Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1 (as long as Rule 4.4.2 is met)?
gold_answer: Under the prohibition, a person shall not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange unless there is an Approved Prospectus in relation to the relevant Securities, and this is framed as being “subject to subsection (3)” and uses the explicit prohibition term “shall not” [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54]. But the scope text narrows that outcome for a particular category: it states that the prohibition in section 61(1) of the FSMR does not apply to the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange of Securities that are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, and it adds that this non-application is subject to the requirement in Rule 4.4.2 [#SRC:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9]. Putting both together, the “shall not” restriction on admission to trading is not meant to bite where the Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, but only if the Rule 4.4.2 requirement is satisfied. So the key checks are: (1) the Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, and (2) Rule 4.4.2’s requirement is met; otherwise the Approved Prospectus condition remains the operative prohibition.
source_text: The prohibition in section 61(1) of the FSMR does not apply, subject to the requirement in Rule 4.4.2, to the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange of Securities that are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1.
target_text:
A person shall not, subject to subsection ‎(3)—
(a)	make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or
(b)	have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange;
unless there is an Approved Prospectus in relation to the relevant Securities.

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and seeks to take that Collateral into account in measuring pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, what approach selection is permitted, and what mandatory constraints apply to approach choice and mixing for the Non Trading Book versus the Trading Book?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT is allowed to recognise the effect of that Collateral when measuring the relevant pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, provided the exposure is determined under the specified measurement basis and the recognition is done in accordance with the applicable recognition framework referenced in the permission [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. Once the firm elects to recognise collateral effects, the Target text imposes mandatory constraints on how that recognition must be performed depending on book classification. In the Non Trading Book, the Authorised Person must choose one of two approaches—either the FCSA or the FCCA—to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, must apply that chosen approach consistently across the entire Non Trading Book, and must not use a combination of both approaches within that book [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. In contrast, for any pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the Authorised Person is restricted to a single approach and must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for any SFT in the Non Trading Book. The Authorised Person must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book and must not use a combination of both approaches. For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, an Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.

question: When a PFP Operator publishes required information for PFP Clients on its Private Financing Platform (including what due diligence it does and its limits), what records must it keep, and for how long, to support what it has published?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator must ensure that certain information is published on the Private Financing Platform it operates and is available to PFP Clients, including (among other items) the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence it undertakes concerning each PFP Prospect, and information about any Body Corporate used as an intermediary and other relevant details about the PFP Operator’s roles or obligations [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]. To support and evidence those platform disclosures, the PFP Operator must also, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of three categories of materials: all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure rules; all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and the due diligence undertaken under the applicable due diligence requirement [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]. Read together, the publication duty sets what must be made available to PFP Clients on-platform, while the recordkeeping duty sets the minimum retention period and the types of records that should exist to demonstrate what was done and communicated.
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.

question: When an MTF Operator decides it may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, what must the MTF do to make sure the offer and trading stay on its platform and that no more than 200 non-Professional Clients can trade?
gold_answer: Under the source, an MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, and the trading model is framed around two groups: an unlimited number of Professional Clients and a limited group of Retail Clients (no more than 200) who have been assessed by the MTF Operator to have appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f]. The target then turns that model into specific operational requirements once the MTF admits the Securities to trading. The MTF must ensure it has effective systems and controls to admit only Securities of Exempt Offers that are made on its own platform, which ties admission to the platform where the offer is made [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. It must also identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, so it can apply trading restrictions to the correct population [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. Critically, it must restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade the Securities, aligning the control requirement with the source’s cap on retail participation [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. The MTF must also support admission and trading with controls for applicable admission-to-trading compliance and user access to Inside Information, including relevant offer documents [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66].
source_text: In respect of Securities offered by Exempt Offer, whether previously offered through a PFP or not, an MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, enabling such Securities to be traded amongst an unlimited number of Professional Clients and not more than 200 Retail Clients which have been assessed by the MTF Operator to possess appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks, in accordance with Market Infrastructure Rules (MIR) Rule 2.8.3. A description of the systems and controls required to be employed by a MTF Operator that seeks to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading is set out in Conduct of Business Rules (COBS) Rule 8.2.2.

question: If an Applicant has less than three years of audited financial statements and the Regulator generally expects quarterly cash reports in that situation, what audited accounts must the Applicant have published or filed, and what key requirements must those accounts satisfy?
gold_answer: If an Applicant has less than three years of audited financial statements, the Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with the quarterly cash reporting expectation in that circumstance, including where the Listed Entity is admitted under the assets eligibility test or where the Regulator considers quarterly cash reports necessary for other reasons such as a cash-box admission [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8]. Separately, the Applicant must have published or filed audited accounts that cover three years, unless the Regulator accepts a shorter period, which is the built-in flexibility for Applicants that do not have a full three-year audited track record [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. The audited accounts must be consolidated for the Applicant and any subsidiary undertakings, prepared under IFRS or other standards acceptable to the Regulator, and audited and reported on by auditors using IAASB auditing standards or other standards acceptable to the Regulator [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. In practice, this means the Applicant must both (i) ensure its audited accounts meet these content and audit-quality conditions (even if for a shorter period accepted by the Regulator) and (ii) be prepared for the Regulator’s general expectation of quarterly cash reporting triggered by having less than three years of audited financial statements [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8].
source_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.

question: If the Regulator thinks a Fund or Sub Fund name is misleading, undesirable, or too similar to another Fund or Sub-Fund name, can it tell the Fund Manager to change it? Does the same kind of power also apply when the problem is with the name of a class of Units in a Fund?
gold_answer: Yes. If, in the opinion of the Regulator, the name of a Fund or of a Sub Fund is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with the name of another Fund or Sub-Fund, the Regulator is permitted to direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff]. The same overall direction-making concept also extends beyond just Fund and Sub-Fund names: the Regulator has the power to make a direction where the name of a Fund, a Sub-Fund, or a class of Units in a Fund is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund, or class of Units of a Fund [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295]. Taken together, this means the Regulator’s permission to intervene is triggered by the same types of naming concerns (conflict, undesirability, or misleading effect), and the Target clarifies that, at least for Fund and Sub Fund names, the direction can require the Fund Manager to implement a name change.
source_text: Pursuant to Section 117 of FSMR, the Regulator has the power to make a direction if a name of a Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units in a Fund is undesirable, misleading or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units of a Fund.
target_text:
Power to make a Direction
If, in the opinion of the Regulator, the name of a Fund or of a Sub Fund conflicts with the name of another Fund or Sub-Fund or is undesirable or misleading, it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a later disclosure about forecast financial information derived from a Production Target after having already made an earlier compliant disclosure, what must that later disclosure still include regarding the Production Target assumptions and any required cautionary statements, and in what circumstances may it omit repeating the detailed assumption and proportion information?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s later disclosure about forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may omit repeating the detailed information that would otherwise be required, but only if it clearly points back to an earlier disclosure that already included the required Production Target assumption content, and it confirms that the material assumptions underpinning the original forecast financial information continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. The earlier disclosure being referenced must have included the required assumption package for a Production Target disclosure, including all material economic assumptions (or, if commercially sensitive, a statement and methodology explanation) and all other material assumptions, and where relevant a statement that any forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, plus the required breakdown of the Production Target across reserve/resource categories and any Exploration Target component [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. In addition, the later disclosure must still include an equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, and likewise must include the corresponding equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: When an Authorised Person uses Total Risk Exposure Amount to apply the 8.0% test in the “lesser of” step for a Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital inclusion, what must be included in Total Risk Exposure Amount, and how does that connect to the subtraction the Authorised Person must perform?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must calculate Total Risk Exposure Amount by adding together specific components: Credit RWA, plus the risk exposure amounts associated with the Market Risk Capital Requirement, the Operational Risk Capital Requirement, the CVA Risk Capital Requirement, and—if it applies—the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement, with the calculation performed after taking into account the specified provisions relevant to that computation [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]. That Total Risk Exposure Amount is then used in the 8.0% T1 Capital requirement that forms part of the “lesser of” amount in the Subsidiary qualifying T1 Capital inclusion method. Specifically, the “lesser of” compares the T1 Capital required to meet (i) the Subsidiary’s solo 8.0% requirement plus its Combined Buffer Requirement and (ii) the consolidated T1 Capital relating to the Subsidiary required to meet the Financial Group’s 8.0% requirement plus its Combined Buffer Requirement [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14]. The Authorised Person must multiply that “lesser of” amount by a percentage based on the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital relative to all its T1 Capital instruments plus related retained earnings and share premium accounts, and subtract the result from the Subsidiary’s qualifying T1 Capital to determine what is included in consolidated T1 Capital [#SRC:848dd3a2-e7e9-4e76-81cd-55b3105d6d14].
source_text:
Qualifying T1 Capital instruments included in consolidated T1 Capital. An Authorised Person must determine the amount of qualifying T1 Capital of a Subsidiary that is included in consolidated T1 Capital of the Authorised Person's Financial Group by subtracting from the qualifying T1 Capital of that Subsidiary the result of multiplying the amount referred to in (a) by the percentage referred to in (b):
(a)	the lesser of the following:
(i)	the amount of T1 Capital of that Subsidiary required to meet the sum of the Subsidiary's T1 Capital requirement (on a solo basis) of 8.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	the amount of consolidated T1 Capital that relates to the Subsidiary that is required on a consolidated basis to meet the sum of its Financial Group's T1 Capital requirement of 8.0% of the Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and its Combined Buffer Requirement;
(b)	the qualifying T1 Capital of the Subsidiary expressed as a percentage of all T1 Capital instruments of that Subsidiary plus the related retained earnings and Share premium accounts.

question: If an Authorised Person sells some of its HQLA during a financial or liquidity stress period to get cash for outflows, and this means it may not meet its LCR Requirement, what must it tell the Regulator and how quickly?
gold_answer: In a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person is allowed to liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows, even if that means its HQLA level falls below what is required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with those outflows [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f]. But if the Authorised Person does not meet its LCR Requirement, or if it becomes aware of circumstances from the stress situation that may result in it not meeting its LCR Requirement, it must notify the Regulator in writing immediately [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c]. This applies “at any time” and specifically includes stress periods, so the fact that selling HQLA is permitted to manage outflows does not delay or replace the duty to send immediate written notice when the LCR Requirement is breached or is at risk of being breached [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f] [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c].
source_text: Liquidation of assets during periods of stress . During a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person may liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows. Subject to Rule 9.3.9, the Authorised Person's level of HQLA may fall below the levels required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with cash outflows during that period.
target_text: Notification if LCR Requirement is not met . An Authorised Person must notify the Regulator in writing immediately if it does not meet, or becomes aware of circumstances that may result in it not meeting, at any time, its LCR Requirement (including during a period of stress referred to in Rule 9.3.8).

question: If an Authorised Person does not meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, what must it do before it can pay a cash dividend or issue bonus Shares, and why do those actions count as a CET1 Capital distribution?
gold_answer: Cash dividends and the distribution of fully or partly paid bonus Shares (or other capital instruments) are both included in what counts as a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26]. So, when an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must first calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with the applicable rule. Until it has calculated that amount and notified the Regulator under the required notification rule, it must ensure it does not undertake a CET1 Capital distribution, which would include paying a cash dividend or issuing bonus Shares [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. In the same period (before calculation and notification), it must also ensure it does not create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, and it must not pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. It must also avoid making payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments until the required steps are completed [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].
target_text:
Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and
(b)	ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7:
(i)	make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: If someone gets written notice to attend an interview and answer questions, are they prohibited from refusing to answer because it could incriminate them or reveal something said in confidence, and does the same “no reasonable excuse” rule also apply to refusing to let documents be inspected/copied or produced under a requirement?
gold_answer: Yes. In the interview setting, a person who is required to attend an interview is first provided written notice requiring their attendance to answer questions, and the interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer just because the answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (with the stated qualification about confidential communications) [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda]. The related prohibition goes further by stating that, subject to the stated carve-out, it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to permit inspection and copying of any information or Document, to give or produce (or procure the giving or production of) any information or Document, or to answer questions, when the refusal is based on the ground that the information, Document, or answer might tend to incriminate the person or might reveal a communication made in confidence (again with the stated qualification) [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]. Together, these passages mean a person cannot rely on self-incrimination or confidentiality concerns as the reason to avoid answering questions at interview, and cannot use those grounds as a “reasonable excuse” to avoid inspection/copying or production duties when required.
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . A person required to attend an interview will first be provided with written notice requiring their attendance at the interview to answer questions. Pursuant to section 206(5) of FSMR, an interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question on the basis that their answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section 209(6) of FSMR).
target_text:
Subject to section ‎210‎(3), it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to—
(a)	permit inspection and copying of any information or Document;
(b)	give or produce, or procure the giving or production of, any information or Document; or
(c)	answer questions;
pursuant to any requirement under sections ‎201, ‎203 and ‎206‎(1)‎(a), ‎(b), ‎(c) and ‎(e) on the grounds that any such information or Document or answer, as the case may be—
(d)	might tend to incriminate the person; or
(e)	is, or contains, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section ‎209‎(6)).

question: If a Listed Entity signs a deal to issue Equity Securities but says it will only go ahead if holders approve, can it still issue the Equity Securities without that approval, especially if the deal would put it over the maximum number allowed under the new-issue limit?
gold_answer: No. If a Listed Entity relies on an agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approving the issue before it is made, the Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing the Equity Securities unless and until that approval has been obtained; it must not issue without such approval. Separately, the Listed Entity is also prohibited from issuing, or even agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the formula unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities. This means that where the proposed issue (or agreement) would exceed the calculated maximum, holder approval is required to avoid breaching the new-issue restriction, and the same approval is also the gating condition for any issuance under the conditional agreement. The approval is also relevant to how the limit is measured: issuances or agreements made with holder approval are carved out from “Relevant Issues,” and certain approved issuances can be counted in the “Base Amount,” which can affect the maximum number permitted. [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]
source_text: An agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approving the issue under Rule 9.7.1 before the issue is made.  If a Listed Entity relies on this exception, it must not issue the Equity Securities without such approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: A Listed Entity must not issue too many Equity Securities without a vote by holders of Ordinary Securities. When working out how many Equity Securities it is issuing (including for the 12‑month lookback items in the cap), how should it count fully paid, partly paid, and convertible instruments, and when can the Regulator decide a different count?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum allowed by the cap calculation unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. To apply that limit, it must calculate how many Equity Securities it is issuing or agreeing to issue using the specified counting approach. Fully paid Ordinary Securities are counted one-for-one. Partly paid Securities are counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities they could become if fully paid up. Convertible Securities are counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities they could convert into [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]. If the Security does not fit those categories, the Regulator may decide how it is counted, taking into account the need to ensure holders of Ordinary Securities have an opportunity to vote on issues that may dilute their holdings, or based on the Security’s characteristics [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]. Using these counting rules helps ensure the Listed Entity’s total is measured consistently against the maximum number that, if exceeded, would require holder approval [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933].
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: When an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, how must it determine the maximum distributable amount, including the required multiplication approach, the profit base to be used, and how the applicable factor is selected by reference to the Authorised Person’s CET1 Capital position within the Combined Buffer Requirement?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must calculate the maximum distributable amount before it can proceed with restricted distribution-related actions, and that calculation must follow the method that requires a multiplication of two components. First, the Authorised Person must identify the relevant profit base: the total of interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital and that accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any relevant actions referenced in the calculation framework [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. Second, it must determine the applicable factor by assessing where its CET1 Capital (to the extent not used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement) falls within the quartiles of the Combined Buffer Requirement; the factor is 0, 0.2, 0.4, or 0.6 depending on whether it is in the first, second, third, or fourth quartile, respectively [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. This maximum distributable amount calculation is a required step when the Combined Buffer Requirement is not met [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].
target_text:
Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and
(b)	ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7:
(i)	make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a Clearing Service from a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, what must it do to make sure clearing and settlement will happen on time, and what must it send to the Regulator?
gold_answer: The Recognised Investment Exchange must do two things that work together. It must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are made to secure the timely discharge—whether by performance, compromise or otherwise—of the clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange, meaning the rights and liabilities that relate to those transactions [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. In addition, if the Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, it must confirm to the Regulator, in writing, the satisfactory arrangements it has made [#SRC:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e]. So, it is not enough to rely on the clearing provider’s processes: the Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure the arrangements exist and are satisfactory for timely clearing and settlement, and it must also provide written confirmation of those arrangements to the Regulator when the provider is outside the specified clearing house categories.
source_text: If a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, the Recognised Investment Exchange must confirm to the Regulator, in writing, the satisfactory arrangements made under Rule 3.8.1.
target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange, when engaging a Clearing Service, must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are made for securing the timely discharge (whether by performance, compromise or otherwise), Clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange (being rights and liabilities in relation to those transactions).

question: When a person is required to attend an interview after receiving written notice to answer questions, what is prohibited as a basis for refusing to answer, and how does that prohibition align with the rule that a person must not treat self-incrimination or confidential communications as a reasonable excuse to refuse inspection/production obligations or to answer questions under an information-gathering requirement?
gold_answer: Where a person is required to attend an interview, they are first given written notice requiring attendance to answer questions, and the interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer merely because the answer may incriminate them, expose them to a penalty, or reveal a communication made in confidence (with the stated qualification regarding confidential communications) [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda]. In parallel, the prohibition in the information-gathering context makes clear that, subject to the stated carve-out, it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to permit inspection and copying of information or a Document, to give or produce (or procure the giving or production of) information or a Document, or to answer questions, on the grounds that the information, Document, or answer might tend to incriminate the person or might reveal a communication made in confidence (again with the stated qualification) [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]. Read together, the interview obligation and the broader prohibition both foreclose reliance on self-incrimination or confidentiality as a refusal rationale for answering questions, and the target text extends the same principle to inspection/copying and production duties when imposed under the relevant requirements.
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . A person required to attend an interview will first be provided with written notice requiring their attendance at the interview to answer questions. Pursuant to section 206(5) of FSMR, an interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question on the basis that their answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section 209(6) of FSMR).
target_text:
Subject to section ‎210‎(3), it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to—
(a)	permit inspection and copying of any information or Document;
(b)	give or produce, or procure the giving or production of, any information or Document; or
(c)	answer questions;
pursuant to any requirement under sections ‎201, ‎203 and ‎206‎(1)‎(a), ‎(b), ‎(c) and ‎(e) on the grounds that any such information or Document or answer, as the case may be—
(d)	might tend to incriminate the person; or
(e)	is, or contains, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section ‎209‎(6)).
